tgt_text.5163: but when the whole is not assumed false, the conclusion is true.
tgt_text.5165: If the major is true wholly, but the minor wholly false, the conclusion is true.
tgt_text.5167: In particulars with a major false, but a minor true, there may be a true conclusion.
tgt_text.5169: If the major is partly false, the conclusion will be true.
tgt_text.5171: III.—1. In the middle figure we may infer the true from premises, either one or both wholly or partially false.
tgt_text.5173: IV.—1. The case is the same in the third, as in the preceding figures.
tgt_text.5175: Particulars follow the same rule, i. e. those with one universal and one particular premise.
tgt_text.5177: If the conclusion be false there must be falsity in one or more of the premises, but this does not hold good vice versâ.
tgt_text.5179: The demonstration of things in a circle and from each other is by the conclusion, and by taking one proposition converse in predication to conclude the other, which we had taken in a former syllogism.
tgt_text.5181: A demonstration of this kind not truly made, except through converted terms, and then by assumption "pro concesso " only.
tgt_text.5183: VI.—1. As to the same in the second figure, in uni­ versals an affirmative proposition is not demonstrated.
tgt_text.5185: In particulars, the particular proposition alone is de­ monstrated when the universal is affirmative.
tgt_text.5187: VII.—1. In the third figure, when both propositions are universal, there is no circular demonstration.
tgt_text.5189: There will be demonstration where the minor is uni­ versal, and the major particular.
tgt_text.5191: When the affirmative is universal there is demonstra­ tion of the particular negative, but not when the negative is universal.
tgt_text.5193: VIII.—1. Conversion is by transposition of the conclu­ sion to produce a syllogism, either that the major is not with the middle, or that this last is not with the minor.
tgt_text.5195: There is a different syllogism, according as the above is done contradictorily or contrarily.
tgt_text.5196: CHAP. IX.—1. As to conversions in the second figure, we cannot, in universals, infer the contrary to the major pre­ mise, but we may the contradictory ;
tgt_text.5197: the minor is depend­ ent upon the assumption of the conclusion.
tgt_text.5199: In particulars, if the contrary of the conclusion be as­ sumed, neither proposition is subverted ;
tgt_text.5200: if the contra­ dictory, both are.
tgt_text.5202: In the third figure, if the contrary to the con­ clusion be assumed, or the contradictory, the same result respectively occurs, as in particulars of the second figure.
tgt_text.5203: CHAP. XI.—1. A syllogism ”per impossibile" is shown when the contradiction of the conclusion is laid down and another proposition is assumed:
tgt_text.5204: it is produced in all the figures.
tgt_text.5206: It resembles conversion, except that the opposite is not previously acknowledged, but is manifestly true.
tgt_text.5208: In the first figure the universal affirmative is not de­ monstrable " per impossibile."4. The particular affirmative and universal negative may be demonstrated, when the contradictory of the conclusion is assumed.
tgt_text.5210: The particular negative is demonstrated, but if the sub-contrary to the conclusion be assumed, what was pro­ posed is subverted.
tgt_text.5212: XII.—1. In the second figure A is proved "per ab­ surdum," if the contradictory be assumed, not if the con­ trary.
tgt_text.5215: In the third figure, both affirmatives and negatives are demonstrable "per absurdum."CHAP. XIV.1—.
tgt_text.5216: A demonstration to the impossible differs from the ostensive, in that it admits what it wishes to sub­ vert, leading to an acknowledged falsehood, whilst the ostensive commences from confessed theses:
tgt_text.5217: in the osten­ sive also, the conclusion need not be known, whether it is or is not, but in the other we must previously assume that it is not.
tgt_text.5219: What is demonstrated " per absurdum " in the first figure, is proved in the second ostensively, if the problem be negative, and in the third figure if it be affirmative.
tgt_text.5221: What is demonstrable "per absurdum," is so also ostensively, and vice versa.
tgt_text.5223: XV.—1. Opposite propositions are according to diction four, apparently, but in truth, they are three.
tgt_text.5225: There is no conclusion from opposites of either kind in the first figure, but from both in the second;
tgt_text.5226: in the third no affirmation is deduced.
tgt_text.5228: Since the oppositions of affirmations are three, we may take opposites in six ways.
tgt_text.5230: From such propositions no true conclusion is deduci­ ble, but from contradictories a contradiction to the assump­ tion is inferred ;
tgt_text.5231: in order, however, to infer contradiction in the conclusion, we must have contradiction in the premises.
tgt_text.5233: XVI.—1. A "petitio principii" generically defined, consists in not demonstrating the proposition, which also happens in many ways, when a person tries to show by it­ self, what cannot be known by itself:
tgt_text.5234: mathematicians are frequently guilty of this fallacy.
tgt_text.5236: This error may occur in both the second and third figures;
tgt_text.5237: but in the case of an affirmative syllogism, in the third and first.
tgt_text.5240: In the consideration of the syllogism, in which it is argued that the false does not happen " on ac­ count of this" (παρὰ του̃το), it is remarked as occurrent, first in a deduction to the impossible which is contradicted, not in ostensive demonstration.
tgt_text.5242: A perfect example of this is, when the syllogism lead­ ing to the impossible does not conjoin with the hypothesis by its media:
tgt_text.5243: it is necessary however to connect the im­ possible with the terms assumed from the first.
tgt_text.5245: XVIII.—1. False reasoning arises from error, in the primary propositions.
tgt_text.5246: CHAP. XIX.—1. In order to prevent a catasyllogism, or syllo­ gistical conclusion being adduced against us, we must watch against the same term being twice admitted in the pro­ position.
tgt_text.5248: In argument, we should conceal that which we direct the respondent to guard against, and the two methods of effecting this are:
tgt_text.5249: 1st, If the conclusions are not pre-syllogized, but un­ known, when necessary propositions are assumed.
tgt_text.5250: 2ndly, If a person does not question things proximate, but such as are especially immediate.
tgt_text.5252: An elenchus is a syllogism of contradiction, to produce which there must be a syllogism, though the latter may subsist without the former.
tgt_text.5254: XXI.—1. Deception, as to supposition ( κατὰ , τὴν ὑπό­ ληψιν), arises if the same thing being present with many primary, a person should be ignorant of one, and think it present with nothing, but should know the other;
tgt_text.5255: or if a man is deceived about things from the same class.
tgt_text.5257: There is a difference between universal and particular science:
tgt_text.5258: for we have not a pre-existent knowledge of par­ ticulars, but together with induction receive the science of particulars, as it were by recognition, after which manner is the reasoning in the Meno, that discipline is reminiscence.
tgt_text.5260: Some things we immediately know, and by universal knowledge observe particulars;
tgt_text.5261: but as we do not know them by innate, peculiar knowledge, we are liable to decep­ tion, yet not contrarily, but possessing the universal, may err in the particular.
tgt_text.5264: as to the universal, the peculiar, or as to energizing, hence deception is incident in as many ways.
tgt_text.5266: From the above, it results that a man may imagine a thing concurrent with its contrary.
tgt_text.5269: If the terms connected by a certain middle are converted, the middle must be converted with both:
tgt_text.5270: in converting a negative syllogism the method commences from the conclusion.
tgt_text.5273: Not only dialectic and demonstrative syllo­ gisms, but also rhetorical, and every kind of demonstration are through the above-named figures:
tgt_text.5274: we believe all things either through syllogism or induction.
tgt_text.5276: Induction then, or the inductive syllogism, is to prove one extreme in the middle through the other, i. e. proving the major of the middle by the minor:
tgt_text.5277: it is also occur­ rent in those demonstrations which are proved without a middle.
tgt_text.5278: CHAP. XXIV.—1. Example (παράδειγμα), is proving the major of the middle, by a term resembling the minor.
tgt_text.5279: It subsists as part to part, and differs from induction because the lat­ ter shows from all individuals that the major is present with the middle, and does not join the syllogism to the extreme, but the former both joins it and does not demonstrate from all individuals.
tgt_text.5280: CHAP. XXV.—1. Abduction (ἀπαγωγη), is a syllogism with a major premise certain, and the minor more credible than the conclusion :
tgt_text.5281: moreover, when the minor is proved by the interposition of few middle terms.
tgt_text.5282: CnAP. XXVI.—1. Objection (ἐνστασις), is a proposition con trary to a proposition, it differs from a proposition, how­ ever, in that it may be either καθόλον or ἐπὶ μέρος.2.
tgt_text.5283: It is occurrent in two figures, because they are used opposite to the proposition, and opposites are concluded in the first and third figures alone:
tgt_text.5284: wherefore, if the proposi­ tion is negative, an objection to it cannot be proper in the second figure, since the objection ought to affirm.
tgt_text.5286: Objections may be adduced from the contrary, the similar, and from what is according to opinion.
tgt_text.5288: XXVII.—1. Likelihood (εἰκός) is a probable proposition, for what men know to have generally happened or not, or to be, or not to be, this is a likelihood.
tgt_text.5290: A sign (σημείον), is a demonstrative preposition, either necessary or probable;
tgt_text.5291: it is assumed triply, according to the number of figures.
tgt_text.5293: An entbymeme is a syllogism drawn from either of these.
tgt_text.5294: 4. If one proposition be enunciated, there is only a sign, but if the other also, there is a syllogism, which last, if it be true, is incontrovertible in the first figure, but not so in the last or second figure.
tgt_text.5296: Τεκμήριον (indicium), is a syllogism in the first figure, which Aristotle proves to belong to it, by the example of physiognomy ;
tgt_text.5297: the first physiognomic hypothesis being that natural passion changes at one time the body and soul;
tgt_text.5298: the second, that there is one sign of one passion;
tgt_text.5299: the third, that the proper passion of each species of animal may be known.
tgt_text.5300: Whatever, however, is inferred in this respect, is collected in the first figure.
tgt_text.5302: -The title of Prior and Posterior was given to the Analytics in the time of Galen ;
tgt_text.5303: in the first, syllogisms are considered in respect of their form ;
tgt_text.5304: in the last, ir respect of their matter.
tgt_text.5305: From certain premises a conclusion being formally drawn, demonstration is deduced, and also demonstrative science.
tgt_text.5306: Syllogisms of this kind, called apodeictic, are the subject of the Posterior Analytics:
tgt_text.5307: dialectic syllogisms, or those from uncertain and merely probable premises, are discussed in the eight books of the Topics;
tgt_text.5308: whilst such as are apparently, yet not really perfect in matter and form, being fallacious, are called sophistical, and are found in the book under that title.
tgt_text.5309: All knowledge rests upon antecedent conviction, and as the general principle which is the basis of all demonstrative rea­ soning is better known in itself and in its nature, so the par­ ticulars from which induction proceeds, are better known to us.
tgt_text.5310: This antecedent knowledge is the major proposition of a syl­ logism, the conclusion being the application of the general to the particular, whence the syllogism is the form of all proper science, nor, though strongly attacked by Ramus, has the lat­ ter critic ever substituted a better inferential method.
tgt_text.5311: From these statements, it follows that things cannot be de­ monstrated in a circle;
tgt_text.5312: neither can the number of middle terms between the first principle and the conclusion be infinite.
tgt_text.5313: Again, these principles and intermediate propositions must he necessary and general, since of what is fortuitous or mutable there is no demonstration.
tgt_text.5314: Of all figures the first is best adapted to demonstration, from its conclusions being univers­ ally affirmative, and as the proof of an affirmative is prefer­ able to that of a negative, so universal is more eligible than particular and direct demonstration to that ad absurdum.
tgt_text.5315: Moreover, since it is one thing to know that a thing is so, and another to know why it is so, we have to consider demon­ stration in two respects, that του̃ ὄτι, or “ the deduction of the cause from a consideration of the effect;
tgt_text.5316: " and the other, του̃ διὸτι, "the deduction of the effect from the presence of the caused
tgt_text.5317: In the second book therefore, we have an exposition of cause, definition, and the acquisition of first principles, and we may remark that so closely did Aristotle consider intel­ lectual knowledge and sensuous perception blended with each other, in the cognizance of these elements, that he broadly as­ serts the loss of a sense to entail the loss of a species of sci­ ence.
tgt_text.5318: The knowledge of first principles, indeed, is not ac.
tgt_text.5319: quired by demonstration, and not being entitled to be called bcience is termed intelligence;
tgt_text.5320: still the conception of the general, is in a manner in the soul itself, and Aristotle did not so derive all scientific knowledge from the senses, as not to draw a strong distinction between experience and science, as also between memory and intellectual thought.
tgt_text.5323: All doctrine and intellectual discipline arise from pre-existent knowledge, e. g. mathematical sciences, also arguments, whether syllogistic or inductive:
tgt_text.5324: this pre­ vious knowledge, however, must be possessed in a two-fold respect, either with some things presupposing that they are, or with others understanding the subject;
tgt_text.5325: with some again, both must be known.
tgt_text.5327: What we know universally and generally, we may not know singly, yet not in the same manner;
tgt_text.5328: indeed a man may in a certain respect know, and in another be ignorant.
tgt_text.5331: —1. Scientific knowledge is possessed when we know the necessary connexion between a thing and its cause.
tgt_text.5332: 2. Demonstration being a scientific syllogism, i. e. a syl­ logism which causes us to know, it is necessary that de­ monstrative science should be from things true, first, im­ mediate, more known than, prior to, and the causes of the conclusion.
tgt_text.5334: Things are prior and more known in two ways ;
tgt_text.5337: the latter are such as are nearer to sense, the most remote are those which are especially universal, the nearest are such as are singular.
tgt_text.5339: The principle of demonstration is an immediate pro­ position, the latter is that to which there is no other prior.5.
tgt_text.5340: A proposition is one part of enunciation ;
tgt_text.5341: dialectic, which similarly assumes either part of contradiction;
tgt_text.5342: de­ monstrative, that which definitely assumes one part to be true.
tgt_text.5344: Enunciation is either part of contradiction;
tgt_text.5345: contra­ diction is an opposition which has no medium in respect to itself;
tgt_text.5346: affirmation is that part of the latter which declares something of somewhat;
tgt_text.5347: negation that which signifies some thing from somewhat.
tgt_text.5349: The thesis of an immediate syllogistic principle is that which we cannot demonstrate, nor need the learner possess it:
tgt_text.5350: what the latter must possess is an axiom.
tgt_text.5352: Of thesis, that which receives either part of contra­ diction is hypothesis;
tgt_text.5353: what is without this, is definition.
tgt_text.5355: He who would possess knowledge through demonstra­ tion, must not only know in a greater degree first princi­ ples ;
tgt_text.5356: but also nothing should be more credible or known to him than the opposites of the principles, from which a syllogism of contra-deception may consist.
tgt_text.5358: III.—1. Two errors occur as to science and demonstra­ tion, the one in thinking that science does not exist, because first things must be known;
tgt_text.5359: the other in the supposition that there are demonstrations of all things, whereas all sci­ ence is not demonstrable, for that of things immediate is indemonstrable, and at these we must some time or other arrive.
tgt_text.5361: There is not only science, but also a certain principle of it, by which we know terms:
tgt_text.5362: we cannot however de­ monstrate in a circle simply.
tgt_text.5364: IV.—1. A syllogism is a demonstration from necessary propositions, previous to examining which last, it is neces­ sary to define, " of every," " per sc," and " universal."2. "Of every" is that which is not in a certain thing, and in another certain thing is not, nor which is at one time, and not at another.
tgt_text.5366: Such are " per se" which are inherent in the defini­ tion of what a thing is:
tgt_text.5367: also those which are inherent in their attributes in the definition declaring what a thing is;
tgt_text.5368: also that which, on account of itself, is present with each thing.
tgt_text.5370: Accidents are such as are inherent in neither way.5.
tgt_text.5371: A contrary is either privation or contradiction in the same genus.
tgt_text.5372: 6. “Universal” is that which is both predicated " of every" and "per se," and "so far as the thing is:
tgt_text.5373: " these two last expressions are equivalent.
tgt_text.5374: Universal is present when it is demonstrated of any casual and primary thing.
tgt_text.5376: An error about the primary universal occurs, as to demonstration, when either nothing can be assumed higher, except the singular or singulars;
tgt_text.5377: or when some­ thing else can be assumed, but it wants a specific name ;
tgt_text.5378: or when it happens to be as a whole, in a part of which the demonstration is made.
tgt_text.5381: By a recapitulation it is proved, that the de­ monstrative syllogism consists of certain propositions " per se."
tgt_text.5382: The demonstrative syllogism is from necessary mat­ ter, wherefore the sophists err, who think they assume principles rightly, if the proposition be probable and true, alleging that to know is to possess knowledge.
tgt_text.5384: Neither the probable nor the improbable is the princi.
tgt_text.5385: ple, but that which is primary of the genus, about which the demonstration is made.
tgt_text.5386: Not every thing true is appro­ priate.
tgt_text.5387: 3. If the conclusion be necessary, the premises need not be so, but when the latter are so, the conclusion must be necessary.
tgt_text.5389: Of accidents there is no demonstrative science:
tgt_text.5390: yet the non-necessary is not to be neglected in disputation.
tgt_text.5392: VII.—1. Three things are present in demonstrations;
tgt_text.5394: axioms, i. e. those from which the demonstration is made;
tgt_text.5395: and the subject genus whose properties and essential accidents demonstration makes manifest.
tgt_text.5396: 2. The extremes and media must be of the same genus.
tgt_text.5398: VIII.—1. There is no demonstration nor definition "per se" of mutable natures, because the universal is non- existent therein.
tgt_text.5400: IX.—1. True demonstration only results from principles appropriate to the subject of demonstration.
tgt_text.5402: The terms must be either homogeneous, or from two genera of which one is contained in the other.
tgt_text.5404: The appropriate principles of each thing are them­ selves incapable of demonstration:
tgt_text.5405: the science of them is the mistress of all sciences.
tgt_text.5407: It is difficult to decide whether a thing is really known or not;
tgt_text.5408: we think however that we know, if we have got a syllogism from certain primary truths, which however is an error.
tgt_text.5410: X.—1. Those are principles (ἀρχὰ) in each genus whose existence, it being impossible to demonstrate, must be assumed.
tgt_text.5412: Of those employed in demonstrative sciences, some are peculiar to each, others are common.
tgt_text.5414: Proper principles are those which are assumed to be.4. Of the three things with which all demonstration is conversant, (vide vii. 1,) we sometimes neglect two.5.
tgt_text.5415: Neither hypothesis nor postulate need exist " per se," nor be necessarily seen, since neither syllogism nor demon­ stration belongs to external speech, but to what is in the soul.
tgt_text.5417: Postulate is any thing sub-contrary to the opinion of the learner, which, though demonstrable, a man assumes, and uses without demonstration.
tgt_text.5419: Definitions are not hypotheses, since they are not as­ serted to be or not to be;
tgt_text.5420: hypotheses also are in proposi­ tions, and definitions need only be understood.
tgt_text.5422: Hypotheses are those from the existence of which, in that they are, the conclusion is produced.
tgt_text.5424: Postulate and hypothesis are either as a whole, or as in a part, but definitions are neither of these.
tgt_text.5426: It is not necessary for demonstration that there should be forms (ἔιδη), or one certain thing besides the many, yet one thing must be truly predicated of the many, so that there must be an universal conception.
tgt_text.5428: In order to conclude, we assume the major proposition to be true of the middle ;
tgt_text.5429: the middle may be assumed either to be or not to be;
tgt_text.5432: The demonstration " ad impossible " assumes that of every thing, affirmation or negation is true.
tgt_text.5434: All sciences communicate with each other, according to common principles, i. e. those which men use as demon­ strating from these, not those about which they demonstrate, nor that which they demonstrate.
tgt_text.5436: Dialectic is common to all sciences, and conversant with all subjects.
tgt_text.5438: XII.—1. There is a certain scientific interrogation, from which the syllogism, appropriate to each science, is drawn.
tgt_text.5440: He who possesses science is not to be interrogated with every question, nor every question to be answered, out those which are defined about the science.
tgt_text.5442: Some argue unsyllogisticaUy from assuming the con­ sequences of both extremes.
tgt_text.5443: 4. Mathematical demonstrations rarely prove the same by many media.
tgt_text.5445: XIII.—1. There is a two-fold difference if the syllogism be not through things immediate;
tgt_text.5446: next, if it be, but not through cause in the same science;
tgt_text.5447: wherefore this consti­ stutes the fundamental distinction between the science, " that" a thing is, and "why" it is.
tgt_text.5449: The ὅτιιs demonstrated, where the media do not re­ ciprocate, also where the middle is externally placed.
tgt_text.5451: There is a difference between a syllogism of the ὅτι and one of the " διότι,” in respect of each belonging to a different science;
tgt_text.5452: moreover, the knowledge of the former belongs to the perceptive, of the latter to the mathematical arguer.
tgt_text.5454: The superior sciences are essentially different from their subject sciences, and use forms.
tgt_text.5457: The first figure is most suitable to science, for the mathematical, and nearly all those sciences which in­ vestigate the " why," demonstrate by this :
tgt_text.5458: the investigation of the "why" constitutes the highest property of knowledge.
tgt_text.5461: One thing may possibly not be individually present with another, i. e. have no medium between them.
tgt_text.5463: XVI.—1. Ignorance, according to disposition (ἀγνοια ἡ Kara διάθεσιν), is a deception through syllogism, occurrent in two ways, in those things which are primarily present or not present, viz.
tgt_text.5464: either by simple opinion or by syllogism.
tgt_text.5465: 2. Of simple opinion the deception is simple;
tgt_text.5466: of that which is through syllogism it is manifold.
tgt_text.5469: In cases which have no medium, both pro­ positions cannot be false, but only the major, when decep­ tion is produced.
tgt_text.5471: XVIII.—1. Universals, from which demonstration pro­ ceeds, depend upon induction, the latter upon sense.
tgt_text.5473: XIX.—1. By those who syllogize according to opinion only, and dialectically, it must be considered whether the syllogisms arise from propositions especially probable:
tgt_text.5474: as to truth, we must observe from things inherent.
tgt_text.5476: If a stated series of terms or demonstrations proceed . to infinity, there are no first principles, since these are in­ demonstrable.
tgt_text.5478: In circular proofs, as in the circle itself, there is nothing first or last.
tgt_text.5479: CHAP. XX.—1. If the predications, both downward and up­ ward, stop, the media cannot be infinite.
tgt_text.5480: CHAP, XXI.—1. In negative demonstration there is not an in­ finity of media in the several figures:
tgt_text.5481: since as progression stops in cases of affirmation, so it must do also in negation.
tgt_text.5484: Of predications, as to what a thing is, there cannot be infinity:
tgt_text.5485: it is to be understood that the predicate is always spoken of its subject simply, and not accidentally, and that it is enunciated of its subject with reference to some one category.
tgt_text.5486: True predications either define their subjects or are accidents.
tgt_text.5487: 2. The theory of ideas is useless as to demonstration.
tgt_text.5489: That of which infinites are predicated, is indefinable.
tgt_text.5490: 4. It is proved from the nature of category, that there cannot be an infinite series.
tgt_text.5492: Propositions are not multiplied by the conjunction of attributes.
tgt_text.5494: If there be infinity of predication, demonstration can­ not exist, and this is also shown analytically from the na­ ture of those things which are predicated καθ̕̕’ αὑτά.
tgt_text.5495: CHAP, XXIII.—1. It follows from the above that one thing may not be always inherent in another, according to some­ thing common.
tgt_text.5497: Also that as there are certain indemonstrable principles of affirmative, so there are certain such of negative demon­ stration.
tgt_text.5499: In affirmative syllogisms nothing falls beyond the mid­ dle:
tgt_text.5500: in negatives, in the first figure, nothing falls beyond that which ought (not?) to be inherent.
tgt_text.5502: XXIV.—1. Particular demonstration may appear pre­ ferable to universal, because by the former we know ap­ parently a thing per se, and therefore know it better;
tgt_text.5503: and because universal is nothing else than particulars, is less conversant with being, and produces false opinion.
tgt_text.5505: It is replied however to the above, that the preliminary observation made in the last section is applicable to both universal and particular, and that he who knows the uni­ versal knows more of the absolute being present than he who knows the particular ;
tgt_text.5506: moreover, that in the universal, things are incorruptible, but particular more corruptible.
tgt_text.5508: Universal alone is cognizant of cause:
tgt_text.5509: hence the uni­ versal demonstration is better.
tgt_text.5510: 4. Particulars more nearly, universals less, approach in­ finites :
tgt_text.5511: the latter therefore are more scientific.
tgt_text.5513: He who possesses the universal, has also the particular, the former also comes closer in demonstration to the prin­ ciple.
tgt_text.5515: The universal, moreover, is intuitively intelligible, but the particular ends in sense.
tgt_text.5518: Affirmative is better than negative demon­ stration, since that is the better demonstration “cæteris paribus " which is through fewer postulates.
tgt_text.5520: The negative requires the affirmative, but the latter does not need the former:
tgt_text.5521: also the latter (affirmative) comes nearer to the nature of a principle.
tgt_text.5524: Since affirmative is better than negative demonstration, it is also evidently superior to the demon­ stration " ad impossibile."CHAP.
tgt_text.5526: One science is more subtle and accurate than another, e. g. " that a thing is," and " why it is," but not separately that it is," than why it is:
tgt_text.5527: " also that which is not of a subject, than that which is of a subject:
tgt_text.5528: and that which consists of fewer things, than that which is from addition.
tgt_text.5531: Whatever things are demonstrated from principles of a common genus, these constitute one science.
tgt_text.5533: XXIX.—1. The same thing may be demonstrable in many modes, both when the middles are taken from the same and from a different genus.
tgt_text.5534: CHAP. XXX.—1. There is no science of the fortuitous, which is neither as necessary, nor as for the most part, but what is produced besides;
tgt_text.5535: hence it is inconsistent with demon­ stration, the latter being one of these.
tgt_text.5538: We do not possess scientific knowledge through sensation, neither is sense science, though they are employed about the same things, for sense apprehends par­ ticularly, science universally.
tgt_text.5540: The universal exceeds the scope of sensuous percep­ tion as to its ascertainment, the perception of the senses being limited by time and place, while science is not so restricted.
tgt_text.5542: Nevertheless, certain things are unknown from a de­ ficiency of sensible perception.
tgt_text.5545: It is impossible that there should be the same principles of all syllogisms, since neither are there the same of even all the true conclusions:
tgt_text.5546: principles are not much fewer than conclusions, which latter are infinite:
tgt_text.5547: moreover, some principles are from necessity, others con­ tingent.
tgt_text.5549: To demonstrate any thing from all things, is not the same with investigating whether there are the same princi­ ples of all.
tgt_text.5551: Principles are two-fold (ἐξ ὧν) and (περὶ ὅ).
tgt_text.5554: A difference between science and opinion consists in the former being universal and subsisting through things necessary;
tgt_text.5555: the principle of science is intellect, be­ cause of our cognizance of axioms by it;
tgt_text.5556: opinion, on the contrary, is conversant with the non-necessary.
tgt_text.5558: Both he who knows, and he who opines, follow through media, to the immediate.
tgt_text.5560: Science and opinion are not conversant with the same subject altogether, the subject of the one being certain, of the other uncertain.
tgt_text.5562: We cannot at one and the same time both know and opine, i. e. the same man cannot.5.
tgt_text.5563: The distinction between discourse, intellect, science, art, prudence, wisdom, belongs partly to the physical, partly to the ethical, theory.
tgt_text.5565: XXXIV.—1. Sagacity (ἀγχίνοία) is defined to be a cer­ tain happy extempore conjecture of the middle term.
tgt_text.5567: I.—1. THE subjects of scientific investigation are four, viz. "that a thing is;
tgt_text.5570: " "what it is.,,CHAP. 11.—1. The preceding four investigations may be re­ duced to two, concerning the middle term, if there be one, and what it is.
tgt_text.5572: The middle is that which expresses the cause why the major is predicated of the minor.
tgt_text.5574: We do not however investigate the middle, if the thing itself and its cause fall within the cognizance of our senses.
tgt_text.5576: III.—1. Upon the difference existent between demon­ stration and definition, it may be observed that we cannot know by the latter every subject capable of the former, nor by demonstration every thing capable of definition ;
tgt_text.5577: in fact, nothing capable of definition admits demonstration.
tgt_text.5579: One part of a definition is not predicated of another.
tgt_text.5581: Definition shows what a thing is, but demonstration that this is or is not of this:
tgt_text.5582: briefly, we cannot have both of the same thing.
tgt_text.5584: In order to collect syllogistically what a thing is, the middle term should express the definition :
tgt_text.5585: he indeed who proves the definition by syllogism, begs the question.
tgt_text.5587: The method by divisions does not infer a con­ clusion, neither does he demonstrate who forms an induction.
tgt_text.5589: By constant division, when a perfect definition is ar­ rived at, we are said to arrive at the individual.
tgt_text.5592: There is no demonstration of the definition, neither if one proposition defines the definition itself, nor by any other hypothetical syllogism.
tgt_text.5594: VII.—1. By an inquiry into the method of concluding definition, it is shown that neither are syllogism and de­ finition the same, nor of the same thing;
tgt_text.5595: also that definition does not demonstrate a thing, and that we can know what a thing is, neither by definition nor by demonstration.
tgt_text.5598: By an examination of the logical syllogism of what a thing is, it is proved that of what a thing is there is neither a syllogism nor demonstration, but it is manifested by both.
tgt_text.5600: To know what a thing is and to know its cause, are the same.
tgt_text.5602: If the cause be different from the essence of which it is the cause, and be capable of demonstration, the cause must of necessity be a medium, and be demonstrated in the first figure.
tgt_text.5604: Whatever we know accidentally that they are, we need not possess any means of knowing what they are.
tgt_text.5606: IX.—1. There are certain natures incapable of demon­ stration, hence their existence and what they are" must be manifested after a different manner, e. g. by induction:
tgt_text.5607: of those which have a cause different from themselves, we may produce a manifestation by demonstration, yet not by demonstrating what they are.
tgt_text.5609: X.—1. Definition being said to be a sentence explana­ tory of " what a thing is," one kind of it will be of what a name signifies, or another nominal sentence:
tgt_text.5610: hence defini­ tion either explains the name of a thing or shows its cause ;
tgt_text.5611: in the one case, there is signification without demonstration, in the other a demonstration of what a thing is, differing however from demonstration in the position of the terms;
tgt_text.5613: One definition is an indemonstrable sentence, signifi­ cative of essence:
tgt_text.5614: another, a syllogism of essence differing from demonstration in case;
tgt_text.5615: a third, is the conclusion of the demonstration of what a thing is.
tgt_text.5617: XI.—1. There are four causes of things, which are all expressed by the middle term, viz. the formal, the material, the efficient, and the final cause.
tgt_text.5619: The same thing may sometimes possess two causes:
tgt_text.5620: so nature produces one thing for the sake of something, and another from necessity.
tgt_text.5622: Necessity also is two-fold, one according to nature and impulse (ὁρμὴ), another with violence contrary to impulse.
tgt_text.5624: In things from reason, some never subsist from chance, nor from necessity, whilst others are from fortune;
tgt_text.5625: from this last, nothing is produced for the sake of something.
tgt_text.5627: XII.—1. As to the causes of the present, past, and future, it is observable that causes and effects are properly simultaneous, and the posterior is not collected from the prior.
tgt_text.5628: The medium also must be simultaneous with those of which it is the medium.
tgt_text.5630: In the cases of past and future, some principle or first must be taken;
tgt_text.5631: and of things which are not universally, but usually, the principles should be non-necessary, yet for the most part true.
tgt_text.5634: In investigation of definition, we must notice a division of things as to extension, since some which are always present with each individual, extend more widely, yet not beyond the genus of the subject:
tgt_text.5635: by wider exten­ sion is meant, that some are present with each individual universally, yet also with another thing.
tgt_text.5637: To attain definition, such must be taken as are each severally of wider extension than, yet all together equal to, the thing to be defined.
tgt_text.5639: In investigating the definition of a subaltern species, we should divide the genus into the individuals which are first in species, then endeavour to assume the definitions of these, next assuming in what category the thing defined is contained, examine the peculiar passions of the first species through principles common to the first and remain­ ing lowest species.
tgt_text.5641: Differential division is useful to the above process, but attention must be paid to whether the predicate be applied prior or posterior.
tgt_text.5643: Nevertheless, it is not requisite that he who defines should know all other subjects, from which he distinguishes the thing defined.
tgt_text.5645: In divisional definition we must attend to three things, viz.
tgt_text.5646: assume the things predicated in respect of what a thing is ;
tgt_text.5647: arrange these as to first and second;
tgt_text.5648: and notice that these are all.
tgt_text.5650: We must in our process, regard those which are simi­ lar, and do not differ, considering their point of similarity, then again, in those generically the same with them, until we arrive at one reason, which will be the definition of the thing.
tgt_text.5652: If we do not arrive at one, but at two or more, the question will not be one, but many.9.
tgt_text.5653: Every definition is universal, but the especially uni­ versal is most difficult to be defined.
tgt_text.5655: Perspicuity is particularly necessary in definition, wherefore metaphors are not to be employed in it.
tgt_text.5657: XIV.—1. Division is necessary, in order rightly to ap­ propriate problems to each science;
tgt_text.5658: first, by the common properties of the genus, then by those of the first species, also if there be any thing common without a name, we must yet assume it, in order to investigate its properties, see to what species it is attributed, and the quality of the things consequent to the anonymous genus.
tgt_text.5659: There is, lastly, another mode, viz. by analogy, i. e. to assume a com­ mon analogous thing.
tgt_text.5661: XV.—1. Problems are identical, which have either the same middle term, or of which the one is subject to the other.
tgt_text.5664: It may be doubted whether when the effect is inherent, the cause is also;
tgt_text.5665: this difficulty is solved by the rule, that the middle term should always express the cause of the inference.
tgt_text.5667: There is only one cause of one and the same thing, from which it is inferred.
tgt_text.5670: If the same thing be predicated of many, except there is an accidental demonstration, it must be shown from the same cause.
tgt_text.5672: If the conclusion is equivocal, the middle term will be so.3.
tgt_text.5673: Things analogically the same will have also the same medium by analogy.
tgt_text.5674: 4. The major term ought to equal the minor in extent, although it ought to exceed the individuals comprehended.
tgt_text.5676: If the same be predicated of things specifically differ­ ent, it can be demonstrated by diverse middle terms.
tgt_text.5678: XVIII.—1. Upon cause to singulars, observe that the middle term ought to be the nearest to the singular, to which it is cause.
tgt_text.5679: CHAP. XIX.—1. In reply to the questions whether the know­ ledge of immediate principles be the same or not, with a knowledge of the conclusion:
tgt_text.5680: also whether there is a sci­ ence of each, or a varied science of either;
tgt_text.5681: lastly, whether non-inherent habits are acquired, or when inherent are latent, the following observations may be adduced.
tgt_text.5683: The habit of principles can neither be possessed nor ingenerated in the ignorant, and in those who have no habit, wherefore it is necessary to possess a certain power.
tgt_text.5685: An innate power, called sensible perception, is inhe­ rent in all animals.
tgt_text.5687: Sense being inherent in some, a permanency of the sensible object is engendered, but in others it is not;
tgt_text.5688: the latter have no knowledge without sensible perception, but others perceiving, retain one certain thing in the soul.
tgt_text.5690: Hence it follows that with some, reason is produced from the permanency of such things, in others it is not.
tgt_text.5692: From sense, memory is produced, and from repeated remembrance of the same thing we get experience, and from experience, the principle of art and science arises, of art, if it be conversant with things perishable, but if with being, of science.
tgt_text.5694: Definite habits are neither inherent nor produced from other habits more known, but from sensible perception.
tgt_text.5696: The soul can retain many successive images:
tgt_text.5697: the uni­ versal first exists in it, when one thing without difference abides;
tgt_text.5698: primary things however become known to us by induction, so that thus the universal is produced by sensi­ ble perception.
tgt_text.5700: Of the habits conversant with intellect by which we ascertain truth, some are always true, as science and intel­ lect, others admit the false, as opinion and reasoning:
tgt_text.5701: intel­ lect is the only kind of knowledge more accurate than science.
tgt_text.5703: Intellect alone is conversant with, and itself the prin­ ciple of, science ;
tgt_text.5704: moreover, all science through demonstra­ tion knows the objects of science.
tgt_text.5705: INTRoDUCTORy.-THE object and title of the Topics have been so fully expounded in the note appended to the opening chapter, in the body of this work, that a brief summary here of the chief divisions will suffice.
tgt_text.5706: The professed design is " to show a method by which a man may be able to reason with probability and consistency upon every question that can occur."
tgt_text.5707: Now every question either concerns the genus of the subject, its specific difference, some­ thing proper, or something accidental to it.
tgt_text.5708: Moreover, dia­ lectic argument may be reduced either, first, to probable pro­ positions suitable to an argument upon occasion ;
tgt_text.5709: secondly, to distinctions of words nearly of the same signification;
tgt_text.5710: thirdly, to distinction of things so far allied as that they may be mis­ taken for identical;
tgt_text.5712: The first book therefore treats of the design of this treatise, the distinction between the different syllogisms, propositions, categories, and the various predication of the word "same;
tgt_text.5713: " also of dia­ lectic, problem, and thesis, with the means adapted to the provision of syllogisms, inductions, and propositions ;
tgt_text.5714: the purport of the subsequent books will be successively pre­ fixed to each.
tgt_text.5715: It is well remarked by Dr. Reid, that though in the enumeration of Topics, Aristotle has shown more the fertility of genius than the accuracy of method, yet he has furnished the materials from which Cicero, Quintilian, and other rhetorical writers have borrowed their doctrine of " Loci."CHAP.
tgt_text.5717: The purpose of this treatise is to discover a method, by which we shall be able to syllogize about every proposed problem from probabilities, and that when we our­ selves sustain the argument, we may assert nothing re­ pugnant.
tgt_text.5718: As a preliminary then, it is necessary to declare the nature and differences of syllogism, in order to appre­ .hend the dialectic syllogism which is investigated in the following treatise.
tgt_text.5720: A syllogism is a discourse in which certain things being laid down, something different from the posita hap­ pens from necessity through the things laid down.
tgt_text.5722: Demonstration is when a syllogism consists of things true and primary, or of such as assume the principle of the knowledge concerning them through certain things primary and true, i. e. such as obtain belief, not through others, but through themselves.
tgt_text.5724: The dialectic syllogism is that which is collected from probabilities.
tgt_text.5726: Probabilities are those which appear to all, or to most men, or to the wise, and to these either to all or to the greater number, or to such as are especially renowned or illustrious.
tgt_text.5728: A contentious syllogism is one constructed from ap­ parent but not real probabilities, and which appears to con­ sist of probabilities, or of apparent probabilities.
tgt_text.5730: Paralogisms consist of things appropriate to certain sciences, and are effected by making a syllogism from as­ sumptions appropriate to science, yet not from the true.
tgt_text.5732: It is not intended in the following discourse to deliver an accurate detail of these, but merely to run through them briefly, it being deemed sufficient according to the proposed method in some way to be able to know each of them.
tgt_text.5734: II.—1. This treatise is usefully employed for exercise conversation, and philosophical science ;
tgt_text.5735: for the first, because we shall hence more easily argue upon every proposed subject;
tgt_text.5736: for the second, because, having enumerated the opinion of the many, we shall converse with, and confute their errors, not from foreign, but from appropriate dogmas ;
tgt_text.5737: and for the third, because, being able to dispute on both sides, we shall more easily perceive in each the true and the false.
tgt_text.5738: It is also applicable to the first principles of each science, as it is the peculiarity of dialectic, from its investigative character, to possess the way to the principles of all methods.
tgt_text.5740: III.—1. He is a skilful dialectician, who can effect a selected purpose by the application of every possibility.
tgt_text.5741: CHAP. IV.—1. As to the particulars of this method, it is found that the concomitants of arguments and of syllogisms are equal and identical in number;
tgt_text.5742: arguments indeed being constructed of propositions, and syllogisms being conversant with problems.
tgt_text.5744: Every proposition and problem enunciates either ge­ nus, property, accident, or definition ;
tgt_text.5745: difference, being ge­ neric, is placed together with genus.
tgt_text.5747: Each of these per se is neither a problem nor a pro­ position ;
tgt_text.5748: moreover, problem and proposition differ in mode, and from the latter you can make the former, by changing the mode.
tgt_text.5749: CHAP. V.—1. Definition is a sentence signifying what a thing is, and either a sentence is employed for a noun, or a sen­ tence for a sentence, since we may define some things which are signified by a sentence.
tgt_text.5750: Such, however, as in some way or other make the explanation by a noun, do not ex­ plain the definition of the thing, though we may refer these to definition.
tgt_text.5752: Property is that which does not show what a thing is, but is present to it alone, and reciprocates with it.
tgt_text.5754: Genus is what is predicated of many things different in species, in answer to what a thing is, i. e. which is fitted to answer the person inquiring what the thing is.
tgt_text.5755: It ought also to be discussed by the same method as genus, whether one thing is in the same or in a different genus with another.
tgt_text.5757: Accident is neither of the above, yet is present with a thing.
tgt_text.5758: It is that also which may be so or not, this last definition is the better, being self-sufficient for the know­ ledge "per se" of what accident is.5.
tgt_text.5759: To accident, comparisons belong of things with each other in whatever way they are derived from accident.
tgt_text.5761: Accident may sometimes and with reference to some­ thing become property, though simply it is not so.
tgt_text.5764: Whatever is advanced against genus, property, and accident, is subversive of definition, but we must not therefore on this account look for an universal method.
tgt_text.5766: VII.—1. " Same" (TO ταὐτὸν) may appear to be divided as to predication triply, viz.
tgt_text.5767: as to number, species, or genus ;
tgt_text.5768: those however are especially called " same," which do not differ in number, and this is attributed most properly in name or definition;
tgt_text.5773: It may be proved by induction and syllogism that all questions belong to definition, genus, property, or accident.
tgt_text.5774: CHAP. IX.—1. As the genera of the Categories are ten, so the definition will always be in one of them.
tgt_text.5775: CHAP. X.—1. A dialectic proposition is an interrogation, pro­ bable either to all, or to most, or to the wise.
tgt_text.5776: Dialectic propositions also are both those which resemble the proba­ ble, and which are contrary to those which appear probable, being proposed through contradiction, and whatever opi­ nions are according to the discovered arts.
tgt_text.5778: The probable, in comparison, will appear to be the contrary about the contrary.
tgt_text.5779: CHAP. XI.—1. The dialectic problem is a theorem, (i. e. a proposition whose truth is to be inquired into,) tending either to choice and avoidance, or to truth and knowledge, either per se, or as co-operative with something else of this kind, about which the multitude either hold an opinion in neither way, or in a way contrary to the wise, or the wise to the multitude, or each of these to themselves.
tgt_text.5781: A thesis is a paradoxical judgment of some one cele­ brated in philosophy, since to notice any casual person set­ ting forth contrarieties to common opinion is absurd ;
tgt_text.5782: or a thesis is an opinion of things, concerning which we have a reason contrary to opinions.
tgt_text.5784: A thesis also is a problem, yet not every problem is a thesis, since some problems we can form an opinion about in neither way ;
tgt_text.5785: almost all dialectical problems are called theses;
tgt_text.5786: neither, however, need be here severally considered.
tgt_text.5788: We need not discuss those things of which the demon­ stration is at hand, nor those of which it is very remote.
tgt_text.5790: XII.—1. In distinguishing how many species of dia­ lectic arguments there are, it is observed that one is induc­ tion, but the other syllogism, and the latter having been described before (top. ch. i.) the former (induction) is here defined to be a progression from singulars to universals.
tgt_text.5791: It is also more persuasive, clearer, more known according to sense, and common to many things:
tgt_text.5792: syllogism, on the other hand, is more cogent and efficient against opponents in disputation.
tgt_text.5794: XIII.—1. The instruments by which we abound in syl­ logisms are four, viz.
tgt_text.5796: 2nd, To be able to distinguish in how many ways each thing is pre­ dicated ;
tgt_text.5798: 4th, The considera­ tion of the similar.
tgt_text.5800: In a certain way there are three propositions fron these;
tgt_text.5801: i. e. distinction of what is predicated in many ways ;
tgt_text.5805: XIV.—1. Propositions must be selected in as many ways as there has been difference about proposition, pro­ posing contradictorily those which are contrary to the ap­ parently probable, and selecting not only the probable, but those also which resemble these.
tgt_text.5807: We must take as principle and as apparent thesis, whatever is seen in all or in most things.
tgt_text.5809: We must select from written arguments, but descrip­ tions must be made supposing separately about each genus.
tgt_text.5811: The several opinions also are to be noted, of celebrated men.5.
tgt_text.5812: Comprehensively there are three parts of propositions and of problems, viz.
tgt_text.5814: it is not easy to define what the quality of each is, but we must learn their distinctive character by habit, arising from induction.
tgt_text.5816: As to philosophy, these propositions must be discussed according to truth ;
tgt_text.5819: Propositions must be assumed as universal as possible, many singulars being made one universal, subsequently employing division, as far as possible.
tgt_text.5821: The disputant should be acquainted with the various significations of a word, and the reason of them.
tgt_text.5823: Ambiguity must be discovered from the diversity of contraries.
tgt_text.5825: In some cases there is no dissonance in names, but their difference is at once palpable in species.
tgt_text.5827: We must consider if there be any thing contrary to the one, but nothing simply to the other.
tgt_text.5829: We must also consider the media, whether there is a certain medium of some, but not of others ;
tgt_text.5830: or whether there is of both, yet not the same.
tgt_text.5832: Moreover, if there is various predication in the con­ tradictory.
tgt_text.5834: We must also notice the same in those predicated according to privation and habit.
tgt_text.5836: Also whether there is any ambiguity in case.
tgt_text.5837: 9. Whether the word belongs to the same category.
tgt_text.5839: Consider also the genera of those under the same name, whether different and not subaltern.
tgt_text.5841: If the contrary is variously predicated, the proposi­ tion also will be, hence the former must be regarded.
tgt_text.5843: Examine the definitions of the composite.
tgt_text.5846: 14. Whether comparison subsists as to the more cr similar.
tgt_text.5848: Whether those under the same name are the differ­ ences of different and not subaltern genera.
tgt_text.5850: Whether of those under the same name there are divers differences.
tgt_text.5851: 17. Whether of those under the same name, one is spe­ cies, but the other difference.
tgt_text.5854: —1. The differences of genera themselves are to be observed with respect to each other.
tgt_text.5856: XVII.—1. Similitude, in the case of things of different genera, must be considered thus:
tgt_text.5857: as one thing is to another, so is another to another;
tgt_text.5858: and as one thing in a certain other thing, so is another in another.
tgt_text.5860: As to those things which are in the same genus, we must observe whether something identical is present with all.
tgt_text.5863: To have considered in how many ways a thing may be predicated, is useful.
tgt_text.5865: 2nd, For syllogistic construction against the thing itself, and not merely against the name.
tgt_text.5866: 3rd, For avoidance of paralogism against ourselves, and for the employment of it against others:
tgt_text.5867: observe, arguing against a name must be altogether avoided by dialecticians, unless the proposition cannot otherwise be discussed by any one.
tgt_text.5869: Discovery of differences, is useful to form syllogisms of the same and the different, and for the knowledge of what each thing is.
tgt_text.5871: Speculation upon the similar, is useful for inductive and hypothetical syllogisms, and for the statement of de­ finitions.
tgt_text.5873: From the above statements, it is concluded that the number of instruments by which we abound in syllogism is correctly declared to be four, as given at ch. xiii.
tgt_text.5875: —THIS book relates to the conversion of the accidental, to problematical errors, to places belonging to name, genus, etc., and to affirmative and negative argument relatively;
tgt_text.5876: also to contraries and similars, and to arguments drawn from addition, and from what is simply.
tgt_text.5879: Problems are either universal or particular, and to both of them those things are common which universally construct and subvert;
tgt_text.5880: the universally subversive are to be first discussed.
tgt_text.5882: It is most difficult to convert an appropriate appella­ tion derived from accident, as to be inherent partly is pos­ sible to accident only, and we must convert from definition, proposition, and genus.
tgt_text.5884: There are two errors occurrent in problems, either from false assertion, or a departure from the established mode of speaking.
tgt_text.5886: II.—1. Of the "places" belonging to problems of ac­ cident, one is, to prove that has been assigned as accident which is present in some other mode.
tgt_text.5888: Also to examine the subjects of predication, beginning from firsts, as far as individuals:
tgt_text.5889: this place converts to con­ firmation and refutation.
tgt_text.5891: To make definitions both of accident and its subject, either of both severally or of one of them, then to observe when any thing has been assumed as true which is not true in the definitions:
tgt_text.5892: we must also assume definitions instead of the names in definitions, not desisting until we arrive at what is known.
tgt_text.5894: Change the problem into a proposition previous to objecting to it, as the objection will be an argument against the thesis.
tgt_text.5896: Define what kind of things we ought, and what we ought not to denominate, as the multitude do, and this place is useful for confirmation and subversion.
tgt_text.5898: III.—1. If an ambiguity of expression escape our oppo­ nent, we must employ the sense most adapted to our own position.
tgt_text.5900: If it does not escape him, we must distinguish the various senses of predication.
tgt_text.5902: Where there is not equivocation, yet in an cases the different relative and actual senses have to be considered.
tgt_text.5904: IV.—1. An intelligible name is to be adopted in the place of an obscure one.
tgt_text.5906: To prove the presence of contraries, genus must be regarded;
tgt_text.5907: the demonstration being from the genus con­ cerning the species, and vice versa:
tgt_text.5908: the former place is false for confirmation, but true for subversion ;
tgt_text.5911: Of what genus is predicated, some species will be, and if no species is, no genus can be:
tgt_text.5912: hence if any position denominated from genus be taken, we must consider its specific possibility.
tgt_text.5914: Definitions of the subject matter must be examined.5.
tgt_text.5915: Also the consequences of the proposition subsisting must be noticed by the subverter, and the confirmer must remark to what the proposition will belong.
tgt_text.5917: Time is to be attended to, if it is any where dis­ crepant.
tgt_text.5919: It is a sophistical place to draw off our oppo­ nent to our own strong point, which topic is sometimes really, sometimes apparently, at others neither really nor apparently necessary:
tgt_text.5920: the last mode we must be cautious about, as it seems foreign from dialectic.
tgt_text.5922: If the consequent be subverted, the original proposi­ tion is, yet we must take care not to make a transition to what is more difficult, as sometimes the consequent, at others the proposition itself, is easier of subversion.
tgt_text.5924: VI.—1. If one of two things concerning a matter be predicated, the same argument comprehends both;
tgt_text.5925: i. e. in those with which one thing alone can be present.
tgt_text.5927: We must argue by transferring the name to the mean­ ing, as being more appropriate to assume, than as the name is placed.
tgt_text.5929: A place is afforded for argument by distinction be­ tween necessary, general, and casual subsistence, being in­ stituted.
tgt_text.5931: Consider whether notions only nominally different be stated as accidents to each other.
tgt_text.5934: Of many propositions contrary to the same, we assume that which especially suits our position;
tgt_text.5935: it is to be remembered here, that contraries are united to each other in six ways, but produce contrariety when united in four;
tgt_text.5936: the two first conjunctions not producing contrariety, which is effected only by the remaining ones.
tgt_text.5938: If any thing is contrary to accident, observe whether it is present with what the accident is said to be present with.
tgt_text.5940: Also whether any thing has been predicated, from which existing, contraries follow:
tgt_text.5941: e. g. if ideas exist, they will be both moved and be at rest, also be both sensible and intelligible.
tgt_text.5943: Whether an accident to which there is a contrary, takes the contrary also, which contains the accident;
tgt_text.5944: this place is chiefly useful to the subverter.
tgt_text.5946: VIII.—1. We must employ the four kinds of opposition, so as to see whether if A follows B, non-A also follows non-B.2.
tgt_text.5947: Also notice whether the contrary follows the contrary, directly or inversely.
tgt_text.5949: In privations and habits we must make an examina­ tion, as in contraries, but in privations the inverse does not occur, but the consequence is necessarily direct.
tgt_text.5951: Relatives are to be used similarly to habit and priva­ tion ;
tgt_text.5952: an objection which however appears fallacious may perhaps be urged, that there need not be a consequence in relatives.
tgt_text.5953: CHAP. IX.—1. What is proved of one derivative of the same word, is proved at the same time of all.
tgt_text.5955: Things efficient and conservative are co-elementary with their products.
tgt_text.5956: 3. Remark whether the contrary is predicated of the contrary, (vide ch. viii.,) for as a principle the contrary fol­ lows the contrary.
tgt_text.5958: We must collect from the generation and corruption of a thing, whether itself be good or bad.
tgt_text.5960: X.—1. Observe whether similars are enunciated of similars, and what is predicated of the one, be also truly said of the many.
tgt_text.5962: Arguments must be derived from the more and less, of which there are four places:
tgt_text.5963: 1. If the more follows the more.
tgt_text.5965: When one thing is predicated of two, if it is not pre­ sent with the more probable to possess it, it will not be with the less, and in the same way affirmatively if present with the less, it will be with the more.
tgt_text.5967: When two things are predicated of one, if what ap­ pears more present is not, neither will the less be ;
tgt_text.5968: or if the less apparent be, a fortiori, the more apparent will be.4.
tgt_text.5969: When two are predicated of two, if the more ap­ parently present with the one is not so, neither will the re­ mainder be with the remainder;
tgt_text.5970: or if what appears less present with the other is present, the remainder will be with the remainder.
tgt_text.5972: Argument is derivable triply from similitude or anal­ ogy, as in the cases of the more present.
tgt_text.5974: If an addition is made affecting the quality, what is added will partake of the same quality.
tgt_text.5975: This place is useful in those cases wherein there happens to be an ex­ cess of the more, but it does not convert for subversion.
tgt_text.5977: Whatever is predicated comparatively, will also be so simply, yet neither is this place useful for subversion.
tgt_text.5979: What subsists at some time and place, and according to something, is also possible simply;
tgt_text.5980: also as to the when and the where, what is simply impossible is neither possible as to any thing, nor any where, nor at any time.
tgt_text.5981: INTRODUCTORY.—THIS book refers to Topics connected with the more eligible and the better.
tgt_text.5984: In the consideration of the eligible, we do not notice things vastly diverse, but those which are near and about the eligibility of which we doubt:
tgt_text.5985: the most excellent is the most eligible.
tgt_text.5987: The more durable, the more certain, that which a wise or good man would choose, or upright law, or the studious, or the scientific, or the greater number, or all would prefer, such constitute the more eligible.
tgt_text.5989: Simply the more eligible is that which is according to the better science, but to a certain one that which is accord­ ing to his proper science.
tgt_text.5990: 4. What is in genus is preferable to what is not in it.
tgt_text.5992: Also what is chosen for itself:
tgt_text.5993: and what is per se to what is accidental.
tgt_text.5994: The cause also per se of good is preferable to the accidental cause.
tgt_text.5996: What is simply good is more eligible than what is so to a certain person.
tgt_text.5999: Also what is present with the more honourable.
tgt_text.6001: Also the property of the better is preferable to that of the worse.
tgt_text.6003: Also whatever is in the better or the prior.
tgt_text.6004: 11. Also the end to the means.
tgt_text.6006: Also what more approximates to the end.
tgt_text.6008: The possible to the impossible, and when there are two efficients, that of which the end is better:
tgt_text.6009: these how­ ever we must consider from analogy.
tgt_text.6010: 14. The more beautiful per se, and the more honourable and praiseworthy.
tgt_text.6012: II.—1. We must judge of the excellence of things by their consequents positively and negatively.
tgt_text.6013: This investi­ gation is two-fold, since it follows both the prior and pos­ terior.
tgt_text.6015: More goods are preferable to fewer, either simply or when some are inherent in others, viz. the fewer in the more.
tgt_text.6017: A thing at its acme of potentiality is more eligible.
tgt_text.6018: 4. Whatever is useful at all or at most times.
tgt_text.6019: 5. What is sufficient of itself when all possess it.6.
tgt_text.6020: Arguments may be derived as to the more eligible from corruptions, rejections, generations, assumptions, and contraries.
tgt_text.6022: The nearer to the good is preferable;
tgt_text.6023: also the more similar to it, and what is more similar to the better than itself.
tgt_text.6024: 8. Ascertain whether the similar exists in things more ridiculous.
tgt_text.6026: Compare relative excellence of the object resembled, since that will be better which more resembles the better.
tgt_text.6028: Examine if the resemblance to the better be in some­ thing inferior.
tgt_text.6029: 11. The more illustrious is preferable to that which is less so.
tgt_text.6036: The best in the simply better.
tgt_text.6039: 17. What we would rather do for friends.
tgt_text.6040: 18. Things from abundance are better than such as are necessary, yet sometimes those which are better are not also more eligible.
tgt_text.6041: 19. What cannot be supplied by another is more eligible than what can be.
tgt_text.6043: What we chiefly desire to be present to us.
tgt_text.6044: 21. The absence of which we less reprove persons for lamenting.
tgt_text.6046: III.—1. Of things under the same species, that which possesses its own proper virtue is preferable to that which does not, but when both possess it, that which has it in a greater degree.
tgt_text.6048: That whose presence produces good, or the greater good.
tgt_text.6050: Judgment of the preferable is to be formed from cases, uses, actions, and works, and these last from those of which they are the cases, etc.4.
tgt_text.6051: The greater good of the same thing is preferable, or if it is the good of the greater.
tgt_text.6053: If two things are preferable to a certain one, the more eligible is preferable to the less so.6.
tgt_text.6054: Again, that of which the excess is more eligible.
tgt_text.6055: 7. That which a man would rather procure through him­ self, than what he procures through another.
tgt_text.6057: Judgment must be formed from additions, with care, however, against the proposition of such things in which what is common is employed.
tgt_text.6059: The same must be done from detraction,10.
tgt_text.6060: Also if one is eligible per Be, but the ether on ac- count of estimation, i. e. such as if no one were conscious, we should not endeavour to obtain.
tgt_text.6062: If one be eligible for both the last, but the other for one only.
tgt_text.6063: 12. The more honourable for its own sake is more eli­ gible, i. e. that which, nothing else resulting, we should rather prefer for its own sake.
tgt_text.6064: 13. Notice in how many ways the eligible is predicated, and " quorum gratia."14.
tgt_text.6065: What is desired is more eligible than what is indif­ ferent.
tgt_text.6066: CHAP. IV.—1. The places last enumerated are useful for show­ ing whatever is to be chosen or to be avoided.
tgt_text.6067: CHAP. V.—1. Places pre-eminently universal are to be as­ sumed of the more and greater, as they will be useful for more problems:
tgt_text.6068: we may render some more universal by slightly changing the appellation.
tgt_text.6070: Causes also are to be distinguished.
tgt_text.6071: 3. If of the same thing one is more, but another less such.4.
tgt_text.6072: A topic of this kind is derivable from addition.
tgt_text.6076: Things more unmixed with contraries are more such.
tgt_text.6077: 7. Also what is more receptive of the definition.
tgt_text.6080: If the problem be laid down partially, all the above-mentioned universal places are useful, whether con­ firmatory or subversive.
tgt_text.6082: Those places are especially suitable which are as­ sumed from opposites, co-ordinates, and cases.3.
tgt_text.6083: A topic is derivable from the more, and the less, and the similarly.
tgt_text.6085: We may subvert not only from another, but from the same genus.
tgt_text.6089: The indefinite can be subverted in one way only, but confirmation is possible in two ways.
tgt_text.6091: When the thesis is definite, we may subvert in two ways, or in three, or in four.8.
tgt_text.6092: We must attend to singulars as to things inherent;
tgt_text.6093: also to genera, employing specific division.
tgt_text.6095: Besides, in what things we may define accident, we must see if no one of these is present.
tgt_text.6096: INTRODUCTORY.—THIS book refers to the Topics of genus and species, similitude, and relation.
tgt_text.6099: In considering topics relative to genus, we may observe that the latter is deceptively assumed, if it applies not to every thing in the same species with that of which it is predicated.
tgt_text.6101: Notice whether it is predicated as accident, regarding especially the definition of accident, if it concurs with the stated genus.
tgt_text.6103: Also whether the genus and species are not in the same category, since universally speaking, genus must be under the same division as species.
tgt_text.6105: Whether the definition of species is predicated of genus.
tgt_text.6107: If the genus is not predicated of what the species is.
tgt_text.6109: If what is contained in the genus is subject to no species.
tgt_text.6111: If what is placed in genus is of wider extension than, or equal to, the genus itself.
tgt_text.6113: If what are in the same species are not in the genus.
tgt_text.6115: II.—1. Consider whether there is any other genus of the assigned species, which neither comprehends the as­ signed genus nor is under it.
tgt_text.6117: Examine the genus of the assigned genus, and always the superior genus, whether all things are predicated of the species, in reply to what a thing is.
tgt_text.6119: Whether the genus partakes of the species, either it­ self or any of the superior genera.
tgt_text.6121: Whether the assigned genus is predicated of the same as the species is predicated of, in reference to what a thing is ;
tgt_text.6122: also whether all those things which are above the genus.
tgt_text.6124: Whether the definitions of the genera are predicated of the species and its subjects.
tgt_text.6126: Whether difference has been assigned as a genus or as a species.
tgt_text.6128: Whether genus is placed in species.
tgt_text.6129: 8. Or whether difference is so placed.
tgt_text.6131: Whether genus is made subject to difference.
tgt_text.6134: 11. Whether no difference of genera is predicated of species.
tgt_text.6136: If species is naturally prior to the genus.
tgt_text.6138: Or the genus and difference are not necessarily joined to the species.
tgt_text.6141: —1. Genus is erroneously assigned, if its subject partake either of some contrary to genus or of what cannor be joined to it.
tgt_text.6143: Observe whether the species is equivocal with the genus.
tgt_text.6145: And if there be not another species of the proposed genus.
tgt_text.6147: Observe also if genus has not been taken in its right sense, but something proposed as genus, which is spoken of metaphorically.
tgt_text.6149: Also if any contrary exist to species, which considera­ tion is multifarious.
tgt_text.6151: The genus is rightly constituted if there be a contrary to species.
tgt_text.6153: Both the subverter and confirmer must notice cases and co-ordinates, whether they are similarly consequent.
tgt_text.6155: IV.—1. Arguments may be obtained from similars.
tgt_text.6157: If privation be opposed to species, we may confute in two ways:
tgt_text.6158: first, If the opposed be in the assigned genus ;
tgt_text.6159: secondly, If privation be opposed both to genus and species, but the thing opposed is not in the opposite, since neither will the thing assigned be in the assigned.
tgt_text.6161: Negatives must be considered inversely, as in the case of accident (vide b. ii. ch. 8).4. Of expression by relation, if species be relative, genus also is, but not vice versâ.5.
tgt_text.6162: Notice whether species is not referred to the same thing both per se and according to genus.
tgt_text.6164: Or according to all the genera of the genus.
tgt_text.6166: Whether genus and species are predicated in the same manner as to case.
tgt_text.6167: 8. Whether those similarly called relatives as to cases do not alike reciprocate.
tgt_text.6169: In as many ways as species is referred to another thing, in so many also ought genus to be, and vice versa.
tgt_text.6171: Notice whether the opposite is the genus of the op­ posite.
tgt_text.6173: If genus and species are stated as related to some­ thing, they ought to have the same ratio to those in which they are inherent.
tgt_text.6175: The following errors are committed by some in points relative to genus.
tgt_text.6177: They refer habit to energy, or energy to habit.2nd, Or arrange habit under consequent power.3rd, Or admit as genus what is in some way consequent to species.
tgt_text.6178: 2. Genus and species ought to be inherent in the same thing.
tgt_text.6179: 3. Species ought to participate of genus " simply," not it quodammodo.
tgt_text.6180: "4. Sometimes by mistake men take a part of species for genus.
tgt_text.6182: Notice if any thing culpable or to be avoided is re­ ferred to power or to the possible.
tgt_text.6183: 6. Or if any thing honourable " per se " is referred to power or to the effective.
tgt_text.6184: 7. An error is incident to those who assign genus as difference, and vice versa.
tgt_text.6186: Also to such as make the thing affected the genus of the affection.
tgt_text.6188: Or declare that of which there is passion to be the genus of the passion.
tgt_text.6190: VI.—1. Examine whether the proposed genus possesses subject species.
tgt_text.6191: 2. Whether also the consequent of all has been taken as genus or difference.
tgt_text.6192: 3. Whether the assigned genus is stated to be in the subject species.
tgt_text.6194: Or whether genus and species are not synonymous.5.
tgt_text.6195: Error occurs if the better of two contraries be as­ signed to the worse genus.
tgt_text.6197: The subverter may argue from the more and less, if genus accepts the more, but species does not, neither itself, nor what is enunciated according to it.
tgt_text.6199: If the more or similar be not genus, neither is that which is assigned.
tgt_text.6200: The above place is not useful to the supporter, if the assigned genus and species accept the more, yet the comparison of genera and species with each other is useful.
tgt_text.6202: To establish genus, we must show that it compre­ hends species with whose nature it concurs.
tgt_text.6204: Genus must be distinguished from difference, by em­ ploying the elements mentioned in ch. ii.;
tgt_text.6205: first, because genus is more widely extended than difference;
tgt_text.6206: next, be­ cause genus is more suitable to enunciate, in answer to the , question, " What a thing is;
tgt_text.6207: " thirdly, because the differ­ ence always signifies the quality of the genus, but the genus not that of the difference.
tgt_text.6209: The genus must be collected from the noun and its derivatives.
tgt_text.6210: 11. Examine whether one is a consequent to the other, whilst the two do not reciprocate:
tgt_text.6211: the disputant must em­ ploy this place, as if genus were that which is always con­ sequent when the other does not reciprocate, but must object to this argument if advanced by the other side.
tgt_text.6212: INTRODUCTORY.—THIS book consists of an examination into whether what is asserted be, or be not, property.
tgt_text.6214: I.—1. Property is assigned either "per se" and al­ ways, or with reference to something and sometimes.
tgt_text.6216: The property assigned with reference to something else, if it be affirmed of one thing, but the same denied of another, produces two problems;
tgt_text.6217: but if each be affirmed and denied of each, it will produce four problems.
tgt_text.6219: That is property " per se " which is attributed to all, and separates from every thing.
tgt_text.6221: Property with relation to another is that which does not separate from every thing, but from a certain definite thing.
tgt_text.6223: Property "always" is what is true at all times and never fails.
tgt_text.6224: 6. Property "sometimes" is that which is true at a cer­ tain time, yet does not always follow from necessity.
tgt_text.6226: Property may be assigned with reference to something else, when difference is asserted to be either in all and al­ ways, or for the most part and in most.
tgt_text.6228: Properties are especially logical, which are " per se," and always, with reference to something else:
tgt_text.6229: that also is a logical problem in reference to which, numerous and good arguments may be framed.
tgt_text.6231: II.—1. What constitutes a good exposition of property is its being more evident than its subject.
tgt_text.6232: 2. Assignment of property is subverted if there be some name assigned in it, of multifarious predication, or if alto­ gether the sentence signifies many things.
tgt_text.6234: Also if there is multifarious predication of the subject.
tgt_text.6236: Also if there be frequent repetition, which happens either when we often denominate the same, or when any one assumes definitions instead -of names.
tgt_text.6238: Also if that be in the property which is common to all.
tgt_text.6240: And if many properties are assigned of the same thing, without distinction.
tgt_text.6242: III.—1. The subverter must remark whether the thing itself is contained in its assigned property.
tgt_text.6244: Also whether the opposite to the thing itself, or what is less clear than the latter, be taken as the property, or in short, what is naturally simultaneous or posterior.
tgt_text.6246: And whether that is assigned which is not always joined to the thing.
tgt_text.6248: And whether the assignor of a present property does not distinguish time.
tgt_text.6250: Whether what is only evident by sense, is assigned.
tgt_text.6252: Whether definition is assigned as property.
tgt_text.6254: Whether it does not necessarily consist with the very nature of a thing.
tgt_text.6256: As to the question whether the assigned be property or not, it is observed that it is not so, if it does not concur with every individual.
tgt_text.6258: Also if the name be not verified of what the sentence is, and vice versa.
tgt_text.6260: And if the subject be assigned as the property.
