tgt_text.6262: And if that is assigned as a property which the thing partakes of, as a difference.
tgt_text.6264: Or if the property cannot be at the same time in­ herent in, but either prior or posterior to, that of which it is the name.
tgt_text.6266: Or if the same thing be not the property of the same things, so far as they are the same.
tgt_text.6268: And if of things the same in species, the property is not always specifically the same.
tgt_text.6270: It being difficult when “same” and “different” are sophistically assumed, to assign the property of some one thing alone, a person may object to many of these proper­ ties, if he make one subject subsistent " per se,” but another with accident.
tgt_text.6271: Still in confirming we must state that that to which a thing happens and the accident, taken together with that to which it is accidental, are not different simply, but are said to be so from their essence being different.
tgt_text.6272: Cases also are to be inspected.
tgt_text.6273: CHAP. V.—1. Observe whether for that which is always the property, something be assumed which is joined to the very nature of a thing.
tgt_text.6275: Whether that whose property is assigned be predi­ cated of some other first, or another of itself as first.
tgt_text.6277: Whether the manner and subject of the property be accurately defined, as either naturally inherent, or from possession, participation, in species, and simply.
tgt_text.6279: Property is subverted, if a thing is assigned as the property of itself.
tgt_text.6281: Observe whether in those things which consist of similar parts, the property of a part or of the whole be laid down.
tgt_text.6283: VI.—1. Observe whether of opposites the properties be opposite;
tgt_text.6286: Observe whether one relative is not the property of another relative.
tgt_text.6288: Property is subverted, if what is predicated accord­ ing to habit is not the property of the habit.
tgt_text.6290: The subverter must consider a topic from affirmatives and negatives, for if the one be predicated as property, the other will not be property.
tgt_text.6292: Whether things non-repugnant be assigned as pro­ perty of repugnant subjects.
tgt_text.6294: Whether the same property be assumed of things re­ pugnant.
tgt_text.6296: Whether of things of the same division, properties are assigned, so as not to keep the same order of division.
tgt_text.6298: VII.—1. Property is subverted also, if case is not the property of case;
tgt_text.6299: and if the case of the opposite is not the property of the case of the opposite.
tgt_text.6301: Also if what subsists similarly is not the property of what has similar subsistence.
tgt_text.6303: Also if what subsists after the same manner is not the property of what subsists after the same manner.
tgt_text.6305: Also if what is said to exist is not the property of what is said to exist, neither will to be corrupted be the property of that which is said to be corrupted.
tgt_text.6307: Observe the idea of the thing proposed, subverting, if it be not present with the idea.
tgt_text.6309: VIII.—1. Whether property is rightly assigned is known from things admitting degree.
tgt_text.6310: 2. The subverter must consider whether the simply is not the property of the simply, since neither will the more be that of the more.
tgt_text.6312: If the more is not the property of the more, neither will the less be the property of the less.
tgt_text.6314: It is subverted if it is not the property of which it is more the property, as neither will it be the property of that of which it is less the property.
tgt_text.6316: Also if what is more the property of the thing is not its property, as neither will what is less so be its pro­ perty.
tgt_text.6318: A topic of subversion arises, if what is similarly the property is not the property of that of which it is similarly the property.
tgt_text.6320: Also if what is similarly the property of a thing is not its property.
tgt_text.6322: Also if it is not the property of what it is similarly the property.
tgt_text.6323: A difference arises between the topic from things similarly affected, and that from things similarly in­ herent, inasmuch as the one is, and the other is not con­ sidered, in respect ot something being inherent.
tgt_text.6325: IX.—1. Property is subverted if assigned in capacity to that which is not, but it is confirmed if assigned to that to which capacity may be present.
tgt_text.6327: It is subverted if it is placed in hyperbole.
tgt_text.6328: INTRoDUCTORy.-This book refers to places connected with definition.
tgt_text.6330: I.—1. Definition is subverted in five ways, viz.
tgt_text.6331: 1st, If the sentence is declared to be predicated of what the name is;
tgt_text.6332: 2nd, If the thing defined is not placed in its appropriate genus;
tgt_text.6333: 3rd, If the sentence is not proper;
tgt_text.6334: 4th, If it does not state the nature of the thing defined;
tgt_text.6335: 5tb, If it be not defined well.
tgt_text.6337: Whether the sentence is not verified of what the name is, must be observed from topics of accident.
tgt_text.6339: Whether the assigned definition is not in its proper genus, or is not proper, must be observed from topics of genus and property.
tgt_text.6341: The remaining inquiry is about proper definition, or its subsistence at all.
tgt_text.6343: The question of defining erroneously is resolvable into two parts:
tgt_text.6344: 1st, Whether obscurity is employed in the in­ terpretation ;
tgt_text.6345: 2nd, Whether the definition is stated more extensively than is requisite.
tgt_text.6347: II.—1. The place appertaining to obscure definition is if an equivocal statement be employed, or the thing defined be equivocal.
tgt_text.6349: Also if it is spoken metaphorically.
tgt_text.6353: Also if an expression be used, not in its proper sense.
tgt_text.6355: Also if the contrary is not intelligible from it, or the definition needs explanation.
tgt_text.6357: III.—1. As to superfluity in definition, we must see whether any thing is introduced which is present with all things, or with those which are under the same genus with the thing to be defined.
tgt_text.6359: Observe whether any part of the definition being ab­ stracted, the remainder defines the thing.
tgt_text.6361: Moreover, whether there is any thing in the defini­ tion which cannot be predicated of all subjects of the same species.
tgt_text.6362: 4. Whether the same thing be stated frequently.
tgt_text.6364: Whether what is universally asserted, adds also some­ thing particular.
tgt_text.6366: IV.—1. In considering whether a person has defined what a thing is or not, we may discover definition to be false, if it be not through things prior to, and more known than, the thing defined..
tgt_text.6367: 2. To assume that definition is not framed through things more known, is possible in two ways, either if it is simply from things more unknown, or from those more unknown to us:
tgt_text.6368: simply the prior is more known than the posterior, but the reverse sometimes happens to us.3.
tgt_text.6369: A true definition is from things simply, and of them­ selves more known:
tgt_text.6370: nevertheless, though simply, it is bet­ ter to aim at the knowledge of things posterior, through those which are prior, yet to persons incapable of knowledge through such, it is sometimes necessary to define through things known to them.
tgt_text.6372: The constant ought not to be defined by the inconstant.
tgt_text.6374: There are three modes of showing a definition to be not from things prior:
tgt_text.6375: 1st, If the opposite be defined through the opposite;
tgt_text.6376: 2nd, If the thing defined be used in the definition;
tgt_text.6377: 3rd, If what is in an opposite division be defined by what is in an opposite division.
tgt_text.6379: The superior must not be defined by the inferior.
tgt_text.6382: We must notice whether the genus of the thing to be defined is omitted.
tgt_text.6384: Also if when the thing to be defined belongs to many things, it is not adapted to all.
tgt_text.6386: It is erroneous in definition to refer the thing to the worse, and not to the better.
tgt_text.6388: And not to place what is asserted in its proper genus.
tgt_text.6390: Also omitting proximate genus to propose remote and superior genus.
tgt_text.6392: VI.—1. Consider as to differences whether those of genus are introduced, since it is an error in definition, not to define by the proper differences of a thing.
tgt_text.6394: Observe whether any thing is divided oppositely to the difference stated.
tgt_text.6395: 3. Or if there be oppositely divided difference, which is not verified of the genus.
tgt_text.6397: Or if it be verified, but the difference added to genus does not produce species.
tgt_text.6399: It is an error to divide genus by negation;
tgt_text.6400: this place is useful against the theory of ideas:
tgt_text.6401: a person may, how­ ever, in some cases be obliged to use negation, as in priva­ tions, yet it makes no difference whether we divide genus by negation or by such an affirmation as to which it is necessary that negation should be oppositely divided.
tgt_text.6403: Observe if species is assigned as difference.
tgt_text.6404: 7. Or if genus be assigned as difference.
tgt_text.6405: 8. Whether also the difference signifies this particular thing.
tgt_text.6407: Or has the notion of accident.
tgt_text.6409: Or if difference or species be predicated of genus.
tgt_text.6414: Whether also the same difference belongs to another genus.
tgt_text.6416: Whether situation be assigned as the difference of substance.
tgt_text.6417: 15. Whether passion be assigned as difference.
tgt_text.6419: It is erroneous to assign the difference of a certain relative, irrelatively to something else.
tgt_text.6420: 17. Observe whether the relation be apt.18.
tgt_text.6421: Also whether the definition be of what is proximate.
tgt_text.6423: Whether that is receptive, of which the thing defined is stated to be the passion or disposition.
tgt_text.6425: Whether the ratio of time concurs with the thing defined.
tgt_text.6427: VII.—1. Observe if any thing else better expresses the nature of the thing to be defined, than the proposed definition.
tgt_text.6429: Whether the definition admits degrees, whilst the thing defined does not, and vice versa.3.
tgt_text.6430: Whether both receive increase, yet not simultaneously.
tgt_text.6432: Whether when two things are proposed, of what the thing defined is more predicated, that which is according to definition is less predicated.
tgt_text.6434: Whether the one is similarly present with both, but not the other.
tgt_text.6436: Whether the definition be adapted to several things according to each.
tgt_text.6437: 7. Whether there is any discrepancy in framing defini­ tions of genera and differences.
tgt_text.6440: Observe if the defined be referred to some­ thing, whether that to which it is referred has not been mentioned.
tgt_text.6441: 2. Whether a thing be referred to generation or energy.
tgt_text.6442: 3. Whether respect be had to quantity, quality, place, etc.4.
tgt_text.6443: Whether in the definition of appetites, a notion of things of like species be added.
tgt_text.6445: IX.—1. Observe whether the definition of the contrary or of the cognates of the thing defined can be attained from the definition given.
tgt_text.6447: Whether if the genus is referred to any thing, the species is referred to the species of the same.
tgt_text.6448: 3. Whether there is an opposite definition of the opposite.
tgt_text.6449: 4. Whether habit be defined by privation, or a contrary by a contrary.
tgt_text.6451: Whether of what is privatively predicated, the subject is not assigned.
tgt_text.6453: Whether that is defined by privation which is not privatively predicated.
tgt_text.6454: CHAP. X.—1. Observe whether similar cases of the definition agree with similar cases of the noun.2.
tgt_text.6455: Whether the definition accords to the idea.3.
tgt_text.6456: Whether in things predicated equivocally a person has assigned one common definition of them all;
tgt_text.6457: for those are synonymous, of which there is one definition, according to the name, and the equivocal suits every thing similarly.
tgt_text.6458: CHAP. XI.—1. Observe whether of composites defined, the individual members are rightly defined, the definition being divided.
tgt_text.6459: 2. Whether of a composite, the definition consists of as many members as the thing defined.
tgt_text.6461: He errs who makes a change in definition, for names .nore unknown.
tgt_text.6463: Observe in the change of names, whether a person does not signify still the same thing.
tgt_text.6465: Whether in changing one of the names, a person changes not the difference, but the genus.
tgt_text.6467: XII.—1. The definition of difference being assigned, observe whether the assigned difference is common to any thing else.
tgt_text.6468: 2. Whether what is defined be existent, but what is ex­ pressed by the assigned definition be non-existent.
tgt_text.6470: Whether in the definition of a relative, that to which the notion to be defined refers, is of too wide extension.
tgt_text.6472: Whether the definition be assigned "non rei ipsius," sed "rei perfectæ.”5.
tgt_text.6473: Whether what is eligible "per se” is defined as though eligible " propter aliud."
tgt_text.6475: XIII.—1. Observe whether he who assigns the defini­ tion of a certain thing, defines it as " these" things, or as that which consists of “these,” or "this together with that;
tgt_text.6476: " for whatever arguments may be adduced to prove the parts and the whole not identical, are useful, but those are especially appropriate in whatever the composition of the parts is evident.
tgt_text.6478: If he defines the thing as not these, but something consisting of these (hoc ex illis), examine whether one cer­ tain thing is not naturally adapted to be produced from these.
tgt_text.6480: Also whether the thing defined is naturally adapted to be in some one first, but those of which it is stated to consist, are not in some one first, but each in the other.
tgt_text.6482: Or if the parts and the whole are in one first, whether they are not in the same, but the whole in one, and the parts in another.
tgt_text.6484: Also whether the parts are destroyed together with the whole.
tgt_text.6485: 6. Or whether the whole be good or evil, but the parts neither, or vice versâ.
tgt_text.6487: Or whether the one be more good than the other is evil, but what consists of these be not more good than evil.
tgt_text.6489: Observe whether it be stated to consist of the better and the worse, of which the whole is not worse than the better, but is better than the worse, though it is question­ able if this be necessary, unless those be of themselves good.
tgt_text.6492: Whether the whole be synonymous with the other part, which it ought not to be.
tgt_text.6494: Whether the mode of composition has been explained.
tgt_text.6495: 11. If “this” thing is assigned with that" (“hoc cum illo "), we must first state that this is with that, or is the same with these, or because this is from those.
tgt_text.6497: Distinguishing in how many ways one thing is said to be with another, observe whether this be in no way with that.
tgt_text.6498: 13. When distinction is made, if it is true that each is in the same time, observe whether it is possible that each may not be referred to the same thing.
tgt_text.6499: 14. Some cases indeed do not fall under the division mentioned, but constitute exceptions.
tgt_text.6501: XIV.—1. Observe whether in stating a composite, the definer has not added the quality of the compound.
tgt_text.6503: He errs, who defines through one contrary alone, that which is capable of both.
tgt_text.6505: If the whole definition is unassailable by a person, from the whole not being known, he must attack some part known, but apparently ill assigned.
tgt_text.6507: This is necessary also, to correct and reform obscure definitions, in order to obtain an argument by rendering something evident;
tgt_text.6508: since the respondent must either admit what is taken up by the querist, or himself discover what the definition signifies.
tgt_text.6510: As bad laws are abrogated for better, so good defini­ tions must be substituted for bad.
tgt_text.6512: It is useful to define with oneself sagaciously the pro­ position, or assume a definition which has been well framed.
tgt_text.6513: INTRODUCTORY.—THIS book refers to the question of iden­ tity, also to places which confirm or subvert definition.
tgt_text.6515: I.—1. Identity must be considered from cases, co-ordi­ nates, and opposites, for if one be the same with a thing, the other will be, and of opposites the opposites are the same.
tgt_text.6517: Observe whether of those of which one is especially said to be a certain thing, another also is especially predi­ cated according to the same:
tgt_text.6518: note that each of those things which are said to be the greatest or the most eligible, must be one in number, if we would show that it is the same.
tgt_text.6519: Xenocrates errs in this omission, as to proving the identity of a happy and a worthy life.
tgt_text.6521: Observe whether one of the things proposed is the same as a third thing, also whether another is the same with it, for if both are not the same with it, they are not identical with each other.
tgt_text.6523: Observe from the accidents of these and from those things to which these are accidents, if there be any discre­ pancy.
tgt_text.6525: Observe if both be in the same category, the same genus, and have the same differences.
tgt_text.6527: If both are alike or simultaneously increased and di­ minished.
tgt_text.6529: If both are equal when the same addition is made tc them.
tgt_text.6531: Whether also the consequences of both upon the given thesis or hypothesis be discrepant.
tgt_text.6533: Whether the same things may be predicated of each, and they of the same.
tgt_text.6535: Whether they are the same generically, or specifically, not numerically.
tgt_text.6537: Whether one can subsist without the other.
tgt_text.6539: II.—1. The preceding topics are useful for the subver­ sion, not the confirmation of definition.
tgt_text.6541: III.—1. As a preliminary to the topics necessary for confirmation of definition, we should know that few arguers syllogistically infer definition, but assume such a thing as a principle.
tgt_text.6543: Next, it belongs to another treatise to assign accurately what definition is, and how it is necessary to define ;
tgt_text.6544: now it is observed only as sufficient for our present purpose, that it is possible there may be a syllogism of definition, and of the very nature of a thing.
tgt_text.6546: In contraries and opposites generally, we must observe whole sentences and according to parts, selecting from the many connexions of contraries, that definition which espe­ cially appears contrary.
tgt_text.6548: Consideration, according to parts, must be carried on, first, by showing that the assigned genus is rightly as­ signed.
tgt_text.6550: Contrary differences also are predicated of contraries, except the latter be of contrary genera.
tgt_text.6552: We must argue from cases and conjugates, as genera follow genera, and definitions are consequent to definitions.
tgt_text.6554: Also from things which subsist similarly as to each other, since the definition of one, will be that of each of the rest.
tgt_text.6556: Moreover, from the more and the similar, in as many ways as it is possible to confirm, comparing two with two:
tgt_text.6557: when one definition is compared with two things or two defini­ tions with one, the consideration from the more is of no use,CHAP.
tgt_text.6558: IV.—1. The places stated and those from cases and conjugates, are the most appropriate, so that we should re­ tain these and have them ready, and of the rest such as are chiefly common are efficacious.
tgt_text.6560: It is easier to subvert than to construct definition.
tgt_text.6562: Also it is easier to subvert than to confirm property, since the latter being for the most part assigned in conjunc­ tion of words, may be subverted by the removal of one word, but he who confirms must conclude every thing by syllogism.
tgt_text.6564: Almost every thing else which may be said of defini­ tion, will also be suitably said of property.
tgt_text.6566: Genus is confirmed only in one way, viz. by being shown present with every individual, but it is subverted in two, i. e. if it is shown not present with any, and not with a certain one.
tgt_text.6567: The confirmer must prove it inherent also as genus.
tgt_text.6569: Accident, if universal, is more easily subverted:
tgt_text.6572: Definition is the easiest of all to subvert, since many things being asserted in it, very many are given, by which it may be subverted:
tgt_text.6573: we may also argue against it, through topics of genus, property, accident, etc.7.
tgt_text.6574: Against ether things, we cannot assume arguments derived from definitions.
tgt_text.6575: Neither can we, except in de­ finitions, argue from some things to others.
tgt_text.6577: Of the rest, property is easiest to subvert, as it con­ sists of many things, for which reason also it is most diffi­ cult of confirmation.
tgt_text.6579: Accident, of all, is the easiest to confirm, and the hardest to subvert, since only its inherency need be proved, and the fewest things are given in it.
tgt_text.6580: INTRODUCTORY.—THIS last book contains a digest of rules for syllogistical disputation, which are to be observed by the questionist and respondent, whence it is evident that not merely truth, but also victory was regarded by Aristotle as an object to be attained in controversy.
tgt_text.6583: In consideration of order, and how we must in­ terrogate, the querist must first discover a place whence he may argue;
tgt_text.6584: 2ndly, he must question and arrange the several particulars to himself;
tgt_text.6585: 3rdly, he should advance them against another person.
tgt_text.6587: The discovery of the place pertains in its consideration alike to the philosopher and to the dialectician:
tgt_text.6588: the lat­ ter's peculiar province is to arrange and to interrogate, since this refers to another person, but the philosopher cares not whether the respondent admits his data or not, if they be only true and known.
tgt_text.6590: There are certain propositions to be assumed besides such as are necessary, (i. e. through which a syllogism arises,) and these are four, viz.
tgt_text.6591: either for the sake of induc­ tion that the universal may be granted, or for amplification, or for concealment of the conclusion, or for greater perspi­ cuity.
tgt_text.6592: Besides these, no proposition must be assumed.
tgt_text.6593: 4. The necessary propositions must not be advanced im­ mediately.
tgt_text.6595: They must be assumed either through syllogism or induction, or some by one and others by the other, except such as are very evident.
tgt_text.6597: Whoever uses concealment must prove his data for the syllogism of the original proposition, by pro-syllogisms.
tgt_text.6599: The conclusions of the pro-syllogism are not to be mentioned, but collected afterwards in a body.
tgt_text.6601: The axioms are not to be taken continuously, but alternately mixed with the conclusions.
tgt_text.6603: As far as possible an universal proposition is to be assumed in the definition, not in the things themselves, but in their conjugates.
tgt_text.6605: We ought to propose as if we did not do so on ac­ count of the subject of discussion, but for something else, and generally concealment of the desired object of conces­ sion is to be observed.
tgt_text.6608: In order to mask design, the interrogator should sometimes object to himself, so as to gain the appearance of candour.
tgt_text.6610: Also affirm that his point is usually asserted.
tgt_text.6614: We ought not to propose what ought to be assumed, but that which this necessarily follows.
tgt_text.6615: 17. Let the querist ask that which he wishes especially to assume:
tgt_text.6616: against some persons such things must be pro­ posed first.
tgt_text.6617: 18. Extend the discourse and insert things which are of no use to it.
tgt_text.6618: 19. Induction and division of things homogeneous are to be used for ornament.
tgt_text.6620: Examples and comparisons are to be adduced for perspicuity.
tgt_text.6623: —1. Syllogism is to be used with dialecticians rather than with the multitude, but induction rather with the lat­ ter :
tgt_text.6624: in some cases he who makes an induction may interro­ gate the universal.
tgt_text.6626: In order to prevent the deception incident to the asser­ tion of similarity, the disputant must endeavour to assign a name.
tgt_text.6628: When an induction being made in many things, a per­ son does not admit the universal, the objection may be de­ manded :
tgt_text.6629: also it may be claimed that the objections be not alleged in the thing itself, unless there is only one such thing.
tgt_text.6631: Against such as object to the universal, yet do not so in the same genus, we must interrogate by division.
tgt_text.6633: If thA objection impede the question, being made in the same genus, we must remove the ground of objection and advance the remainder, making it universal.
tgt_text.6635: This must also be done when there is a denial without an objection.
tgt_text.6636: 7. Direct demonstration is preferable to the deduction “ ad absurdum."8. Things are to be proposed which are difficult of ob­ jection.
tgt_text.6638: The conclusion must not be made a matter of question.
tgt_text.6640: Not every universal is a dialectic proposition, the latter being one to which we can reply " yes " or " no."11.
tgt_text.6641: He interrogates badly who questions one reason for a long time.
tgt_text.6643: III.—1. Things naturally first and last are difficult to attack, but easy to defend.
tgt_text.6644: 2. Those proximate to the principle are difficult to be impugned.
tgt_text.6646: Those definitions are most difficult of attack which employ such names as render it uncertain whether they are predicated simply or multifariously, properly or metaphor­ ically.
tgt_text.6648: Every problem difficult of attack must be supposed to require definition.
tgt_text.6650: Or as of those things predicated multifariously.
tgt_text.6652: Or as not remote from principles.
tgt_text.6653: 7. Or from the mode to which we are to refer the doubt being obscure to us.8.
tgt_text.6654: It is difficult to argue when the definition is badly enunciated.
tgt_text.6656: The querist and the teacher are not similarly to re­ quire a thing to be laid down.
tgt_text.6658: It is the querist's duty to make the respondent assert absurdities:
tgt_text.6659: the respondent's, to remove the apparent absurdity from himself to the thesis.
tgt_text.6662: As a different method in dispute is to be ob­ served by the teacher, the contentious, and the inquirer, it is necessary to remark that the thesis laid down may be either probable, improbable, or neither:
tgt_text.6663: whichever it is, the querist always concludes its opposite.
tgt_text.6665: In the case of improbable thesis, the respondent mutt neither grant that which is not simply apparent, nor what is less so than the conclusion.
tgt_text.6667: If the thesis be simply probable, the conclusion will be simply improbable:
tgt_text.6668: such a thesis must be laid down as is less improbable than the conclusion.
tgt_text.6670: The same rule must be observed, if the thesis be neither.
tgt_text.6672: If the thesis be simply probable or improbable, we must compare it with the apparently true:
tgt_text.6673: if it be neither, we must refer it to the respondent.
tgt_text.6675: If the respondent defends another's opinion, we must affirm or deny with reference to the entertainment of strange theories.
tgt_text.6677: As to admissible points, if a statement be pro­ bable and irrelevant, we must admit it when stated to be probable:
tgt_text.6678: if improbable and irrelevant, we must admit it with an intimation of its improbability:
tgt_text.6679: if it be probable and relevant, we must allow its apparent truth, but state that is too near the original proposition, and that this being admitted, the position is subverted:
tgt_text.6680: if it be relevant, but improbable, we must assert its folly:
tgt_text.6681: if neither probable, nor improbable, nor relevant, we must grant it with no definition:
tgt_text.6682: if relevant, we must assert that from its being posited the original position is subverted.
tgt_text.6684: They do not syllogize well, who argue from things more improbable than the conclusion.
tgt_text.6686: VII.—1. The respondent must acknowledge his in­ comprehension of the obscure.
tgt_text.6687: 2. He must also signify what is multifariously predi­ cated, and why it is partly false and partly true, in order to prove that he perceived the ambiguity at first.
tgt_text.6689: VIII.—1. He argues perversely, who neither has any thing to urge against an induction, nor whence he can prove the contrary.
tgt_text.6691: Perversity in argument is defined to be a responsion, contrary to the stated modes destructive of syllogism.
tgt_text.6692: CHAP. IX.—1. The disputant ought to set out to himself in argument the thesis and the definition.
tgt_text.6693: 2. But must not defend an improbable hypothesis.a.
tgt_text.6694: An hypothesis is improbable, either from which ab.
tgt_text.6696: or such as the more depraved dispositions select, and which is contrary to the will.
tgt_text.6697: CHAP. X.—1. Such arguments as collect the false, must be solved by subverting the ground of the falsity.
tgt_text.6699: There are four ways of preventing the conclusiveness of an argument, viz.
tgt_text.6701: By subverting the ground of the falsity.
tgt_text.6703: 3rdly, By objecting to the questions made.
tgt_text.6707: Of the above, the first alone is a solution, the others are certain impediments to the conclusions.
tgt_text.6709: The reprehension of arguments themselves differs from that of the persons employing them, as some­ times the person questioned is the cause of erroneous dis­ cussion.
tgt_text.6711: We must object sometimes to the speaker, sometimes to the thesis.3.
tgt_text.6712: Arguments of this kind, being for the sake of exercise, the false must be sometimes collected and subverted, even through the false.
tgt_text.6714: In transferring the reasoning, it should be done dia­ ectically and not contentiously.
tgt_text.6716: An argument may be bad, yet the questionist may conduct it well.
tgt_text.6718: Bad arguments arise from men asserting contraries, and admitting what they at first denied.
tgt_text.6719: 7. Reprehensions of argument per se are five:
tgt_text.6721: 1st, When nothing is concluded from the questions.
tgt_text.6722: 2nd, When there is no syllogism against the thesis, from the things and in the way described.
tgt_text.6724: If there be a syllogism from ad­ ditions, worse than those questioned, and less probable thai the conclusion.
tgt_text.6725: 4th, If certain things are taken away when more has been assumed than was necessary.
tgt_text.6726: 5th, If from things more improbable and less credible than the conclusion, or from things requiring more labour to demon­ strate than the problem.
tgt_text.6728: Argument may be reprehensible per se, yet commend­ able as to the problem, or vice versâ.9.
tgt_text.6729: When the argument demonstrates, yet there is some­ thing else irrelevant to the conclusion, and there should appear to be a syllogism, (which however there is not,) it will be a sophism.10.
tgt_text.6730: A philosophema is a demonstrative syllogism.
tgt_text.6731: 11. An epicheirema is a dialectic syllogism..12.
tgt_text.6732: A sophism is a contentious syllogism.
tgt_text.6734: An aporema is a dialectic syllogism of contradiction.
tgt_text.6736: If a demonstration occurs from two propositions of unequal probability, what is demonstrated may be more probable than either.
tgt_text.6738: also to prove from things not evident, as to the cause whence the reason­ ing proceeds.
tgt_text.6740: XII.—1. An argument is clear which requires no fur­ ther interrogation.
tgt_text.6742: Also when things are assumed from which the con­ clusion necessarily results, but the argument concludes through conclusions, proved through pro-syllogisms:
tgt_text.6743: also if any thing very probable is deficient.
tgt_text.6745: An argument is false in four ways.
tgt_text.6747: When it only appears conclusive, i. e. is a contentious syllogism.
tgt_text.6750: Or in an erro­ neous method.
tgt_text.6752: 4. If the reasoning is false it is the fault of the arguer, yet sometimes inadvertently.
tgt_text.6754: Wherefore the first consideration of argument per se will be, whether it concludes:
tgt_text.6755: next, whether it concludes the true or false:
tgt_text.6759: In the discussion of "petitio principii" and contraries as to opinion, the former seems to occur in five ways.
tgt_text.6761: When that is "begged" which ought to be proved:
tgt_text.6763: When the universal is " begged of what ought to be particularly proved.3rd,
tgt_text.6764: When proposing to demonstrate the universal, a per­ son begs the particular.
tgt_text.6765: 4th, When dividing the problem, he " begs " the question at issue.
tgt_text.6766: 5th, When he begs one of those which are necessarily consequent to each other.
tgt_text.6768: Contraries are also " begged " in five ways, viz.,1st, By demanding the opposites, affirmation, and nega­ tion.
tgt_text.6770: 3rdly, If demanding universal to be granted, a person should require contradiction particularly.
tgt_text.6771: 4thly, If the contrary is begged to the necessary result of the posita.5thly, If two such things are claimed from which there will be an opposite contradiction.
tgt_text.6773: The difference between the above is, that the error of “petitio principii" belongs to the conclusion, but contraries are in the propositions.
tgt_text.6776: As a preliminary of argumentative exercise, we must be accustomed to convert arguments.
tgt_text.6778: To convert is, by changing the conclusion with the remaining interrogations, to subvert one of the data.
tgt_text.6780: Argument is to be considered affirmatively and nega­ tively, as to every thesis.
tgt_text.6782: We must dispute with ourselves if necessary.
tgt_text.6784: Arguments about the same thesis, must be selected and compared.
tgt_text.6785: 6. The results of each hypothesis are to be noticed.
tgt_text.6787: A naturally good disposition is requisite for this exer­ cise, and such disposition consists in ability to select pro­ perly the true, and to avoid the false.
tgt_text.6789: A thorough knowledge is requisite of the most usual arguments, especially as to primary theses.
tgt_text.6791: Also abundance and readiness in definitions.
tgt_text.6793: Also promptitude about principles, and a tenacious memory for propositions;
tgt_text.6794: a common proposition, rather than an argument, should be committed to memory.
tgt_text.6796: An adversary's single argument is to be divided into many:
tgt_text.6797: this may be done by withdrawal from things allied to the subject matter.
tgt_text.6798: 12. Universal records of arguments must be made.
tgt_text.6799: 13. The contrary mode is to be adopted by the disputant himself, who is to avoid the universal.
tgt_text.6800: 14. Inductive arguments are to be assigned to the young, syllogistic ones to the practised man.15.
tgt_text.6801: Propositions must be assumed from those skilful in syllogism, and comparisons from the inductive.
tgt_text.6803: The object of a dialectic exercise is to derive either a syllogism, or a solution, or a proposition, or an objection, or whether there has been a right question, and about what.
tgt_text.6805: Exercise is on account of power, especially in pro­ position and objection.
tgt_text.6807: To propose is to make many things one:
tgt_text.6808: to object is to make one many.
tgt_text.6810: Not every casual person is to be disputed with, lest we fall into depraved and contentious disputation.
tgt_text.6812: Universal arguments being with more difficulty sup­ plied, yet of the most general application, are especially to be sought.
tgt_text.6813: INTRODUCTORy.-A fallacy occupies the same position to sound argument, as hypocrisy does to virtue, since it is error under the mask of truth.
tgt_text.6814: Since, however, the human mind would never be deceived extraneously, except it pos­ sessed an affinity to deception in itself, the detection of sophis­ try is no less necessary to the mind's individual deduction of truth by its own processes, than it is for its defence against the assailment of another.
tgt_text.6815: It is fair to attribute all fallacies to a mistake of the con­ nexion existing between the primary concept and its verbal sign ;
tgt_text.6816: for if the latter be not an appropriate exponent of the former, it is clear that the simple becomes the multiform, and the relation of A to B as existent in the mind of the speaker, does not present the same combination of idea to the mind of the hearer.
tgt_text.6817: I say this to place at once upon simple ground the actual nature of sophistry in idea, by removing the dif­ fuse dogmatism which has obscured the proper understand­ ing of it.
tgt_text.6818: Aristotle reduces fallacies in diction to six, which belong to ambiguity in 1. sense, 2. manner, 3 and 4 syntax, 5. accent, 6. figure of speech ;
tgt_text.6819: and besides these annexes, seven fallacies not in diction, but in the thing itself, all which latter, he shows may be brought under ignoratio elenchi.
tgt_text.6820: Besides this enumeration, there are many other points in the treatise, con­ cerning the management of syllogistical dispute, and its im­ portance cannot be overrated when we recollect that the very essence of evil, characterizing falsity, is its possessing a cer­ tain portion of mutilated truth, which falsity, under the form of genuine argument, may by the misapplication of words, or the misrepresentation of a principle, surreptitiously introduce incompetent reasoning, to disturb the formal and material laws of human thought.
tgt_text.6823: Those are not always true syllogisms which appear so, as in other things neither is that really noble nor genuine which seems so, both in the case of what is animate and inanimate.
tgt_text.6825: An elenchus is a syllogism with contradiction of a conclusion.
tgt_text.6827: Its most natural place is from names, since using names as symbols of things, we think that what happens to the one, does also to the other.
tgt_text.6829: The unskilful in the power of names is most exposed to paralogism.
tgt_text.6831: As some men rather desire to seem than to be wise, so the sophist is a trader from apparent, but not real wisdom.
tgt_text.6833: It is the duty of the skilful man not to practise, but to expose deception;
tgt_text.6834: this consists in being able to give and receive a reason.
tgt_text.6836: The following treatise is intended for the investi­ gation of such arguments from which sophistical power and its various sources may be understood.
tgt_text.6838: II.—1. There are four genera of arguments in disputa­ tion, viz. the didactic, the dialectic, the peirastic or tenta­ tive, and the contentious.
tgt_text.6840: The didactic syllogize from the proper principles of each discipline.
tgt_text.6841: 3. The dialectic collect contradiction from probabilities.
tgt_text.6842: 4. The peirastic conclude from things appearing to the respondent, and which he must know, who pretends to science.
tgt_text.6844: The contentious infer, or seem to infer, from the ap­ parently probable.
tgt_text.6846: The demonstrative having been discussed in the Ana­ lytics, and the dialectic and peirastic in the Topics, the discussion is now about the contentious.
tgt_text.6848: III.—1. The objects which disputants have in view are five, viz.
tgt_text.6853: 5. To make the opponent trifle, or repeat himself, or what seems to be each of these.
tgt_text.6854: The order stated presents the comparative preference of each mode entertained by the sophist.
tgt_text.6856: IV.—1. Elenchus may be employed either, 1st, With diction ;
tgt_text.6859: Elenchus with diction contains six modes, viz. equivo­ cation, ambiguity, composition, division, accent, figure of speech.3.
tgt_text.6860: The modes of the equivocal and ambiguous are three:
tgt_text.6861: 1. When the sentence signifies properly many things.
tgt_text.6862: 2. When we are accustomed thus to speak.
tgt_text.6863: 3. When the con­ joined signifies many things, but when separate is taken simply.
tgt_text.6865: In the fallacy of composition, the same term is taken, first, in a distinctive, next, in a collective sense:
tgt_text.6866: in division it is vice versa.
tgt_text.6868: Errors in accent are chiefly incident to writing.
tgt_text.6870: Those from figure of speech are when the gender is interpreted wrongly, or a confusion is made in the Cate­ gories.
tgt_text.6872: V.—1. Paralogisms without diction are seven, 1. From accident.
tgt_text.6873: 2. From what is asserted simply or not simply.
tgt_text.6877: 6. From placing non causa pro causa.
tgt_text.6879: 2. Paralogism from accident is when a thing is required to be granted similarly present with a subject and accident.
tgt_text.6881: From the simply and not simply, when what is predi­ cated in part is assumed as spoken simply;
tgt_text.6882: in some cases this paralogism is latent.
tgt_text.6884: From absence of definition of syllogism or elenchus, in fact, in an extensive sense every fallacy is an ignoratio elenchi.5.
tgt_text.6885: Fallacies from petitio principii arise from as many ways as we can beg the original question, they seem to confute from mistaken identity.
tgt_text.6887: The elenchus from the consequent arises from fancy­ ing that.
tgt_text.6889: 7. From non causa pro causa is, when what is causeless is taken as if the elenchus arose from it, this happens in syllogisms ad impossibile.
tgt_text.6891: From making two interrogations one, a fallacy arises when neglecting that there are many, we answer as if to one interrogation.
tgt_text.6892: In some cases it is easy, in others diffi­ cult, to detect this fallacy.
tgt_text.6894: VI.—1. All deceptions may be referred to ignorance of the elenchus, and of syllogistic art.
tgt_text.6896: Paralogisms from diction are either from two-fold signification;
tgt_text.6897: a sentence not being the same, or the name being different.
tgt_text.6899: If there is not a syllogism of accident, there is not an . elenchus, the former frequently occurs between artists and unscientific men.4.
tgt_text.6900: Those " in a certain respect and simply," are from the affirmation and negation being not of the same thing.
tgt_text.6904: 6. Those from petitio principii and admitting non causa pro causa, become manifest by definition.
tgt_text.6906: Those from the consequent are a part of accident, dif­ fering only in that we can assume accident only in one thing, but the consequent in many things.
tgt_text.6908: Paralogisms, from making many questions one, consist in not distinctly unfolding the definition of the proposition.
tgt_text.6910: VII.—1. Deception from equivocation and ambiguity, arises from inability to distinguish what is variously pre­ dicated.
tgt_text.6911: 2. From composition and division, from imagining no dif­ ference to exist between a conjoined and divided sentence.
tgt_text.6912: 3. From accent, because as sometimes accent does not affect the sense, so when the latter.
tgt_text.6913: is changed, we take it as the same.
tgt_text.6914: 4. From figure of speech, because when words have the ame figure, we wrongly take them in the same way.
tgt_text.6916: From accident triply, by not distinguishing between the same and different, between one and many, and from ignorance as to all things which are said of the attribute being said of the subject.
tgt_text.6918: From the consequent as being a certain part of acci­ dent, we erroneously take it universally.
tgt_text.6920: From defective definition and from those " in a certain respect and simply," because the difference is small, like­ wise in the case of petitio principii.
tgt_text.6922: VIII.—1. A sophistical elenchus and syllogism are not only such as are apparent, but not real, but also the real, yet which appear falsely appropriate to a thing.
tgt_text.6924: Sophistical elenchi, though they syllogistically infer contradiction, do not render manifest the ignorance of the opponent.
tgt_text.6926: False syllogisms will be derived from as many places as apparent elenchus :
tgt_text.6927: the latter is from parts of the true.
tgt_text.6929: A sophistical elenchus is not simply so, but against some person, and a syllogism likewise.
tgt_text.6930: CHAP. IX.—1. We must not assume from how many places confutation by elenchus occurs, without universal science.
tgt_text.6931: 2. There are true elenchi, since in what we may demon­ strate, we may also confute him who contradicts the truth;
tgt_text.6932: hence we must be scientifically cognizant of the principles of the several arts.
tgt_text.6934: Places are not to be assumed of all elenchi, but of those which belong to dialectic, and are common to every art and faculty.
tgt_text.6936: The scientific man ought to investigate the elenchus in each science;
tgt_text.6937: that which falls under no art, but is from things common, belongs to dialectics.
tgt_text.6939: The dialectician should be able to assume from what number of particulars through common propositions, either a real or apparent elenchus, dialectic or apparently dialectic, is produced.
tgt_text.6941: They err, who state that some arguments belong to the name, but others to the reason, since the one only de­ rives its effect from the signification given to it by the other.
tgt_text.6943: The immediate discussion of an elenchus is absurd, as that of a syllogism ought to precede it.
tgt_text.6945: The cause of deception is either in the syllogism or in the contradiction, or in both, if the elenchus be apparent.
tgt_text.6946: This statement is confirmed by mathematical questions.
tgt_text.6948: In order to avoid equivocation, if the questionist should be required, where distinction is made, to point out the fal­ lacy, the demand will be absurd, since not only may the querist himself not perceive the fallacy, but such a process would be not disputation, but teaching.
tgt_text.6949: CHAP. XI.—1. To postulate affirmation or denial is not the province of the demonstrative, but of the peirastic art.
tgt_text.6951: The dialectician considers things common, the sophist does this apparently.
tgt_text.6953: The contentious and sophistical syllogism are one, ap­ parently syllogistic about things with which the peirastic dialectic is conversant, but false descriptions are not con­ tentious.
tgt_text.6955: Those who make conquest their object are contentious, those who strive for the sake of glory, which tends to gain, are sophists.
tgt_text.6957: The sophistical art is defined to be a certain art of making money from apparent wisdom.
tgt_text.6959: The contentious and sophistical employ the same ar­ guments, but so far as the latter are used for apparent victory, they are contentious, and so far as they are for apparent wisdom, they are sophistical.
tgt_text.6961: The contentious man stands in relation to the dialec­ tician, as the false describer to the geometrician.
tgt_text.6963: The dialectician is neither in any definite genus, nor is he such as the universal philosopher, since neither are all things in one certain genus, nor are demonstrative arts in­ terrogative, which last is the characteristic of dialectic.
tgt_text.6965: Dialectic is also peirastic, the latter being the science of nothing definite, but is conversant with all things.
tgt_text.6967: All men, even idiots, use after a certain manner dia­ lectic and peirastic, and partake without art of the subject of dialectic.
tgt_text.6968: 11. The contentious will not be paralogistic from a certain definite genus of principles, but will be about every genus.
tgt_text.6969: CHAP XII.— .1. With regard to showing some false assertion, it is remarked that this generally happens from a certain manner of inquiry, and through interrogation, e. g. to inter­ rogate nothing definitely laid down, and to ask many ques­ tions requiring a person to declare his opinion.
tgt_text.6971: Though less common than formerly, yet the element of obtaining something false is to question no thesis imme­ diately, but to assert that the question is made from the desire of learning.
tgt_text.6973: To prove a false assertion, a proper sophistical place is to bring the opponent to the arguer's strong point.
tgt_text.6975: To prove paradoxes, ascertain what the philosophers of the opponent's order assert paradoxical.
tgt_text.6977: From volitions, the secret wish of the mind, and ap­ parent opinions, paradoxes may be elicited, indeed generally the place of causing paradoxical assertion is very extensive.
tgt_text.6980: From the opinion of the wise and of the multitude, indeed some questions have a paradoxical answer either way.
tgt_text.6982: XIII.—1. Loquacious trifling is produced from such arguments as belong to relative notions, or wherein there are habits, or passions, or some such thing manifested in the definition of the predicates.
tgt_text.6983: Generally it is from the in­ quiry not being added as to the meaning of the double enunciation.
tgt_text.6985: XIV.—1. Solecism may be produced without appearing to do so, and not produced when it apparently is.
tgt_text.6986: 2. Almost all apparent solecisms are from hoc, that is, the neuter gender.
tgt_text.6988: Solecism resembles fallacy from figure of speech, from things not similar being similarly assumed.
tgt_text.6990: In order to conceal, it is necessary to arrange the elements of interrogations.
tgt_text.6992: XV.—1. Certain artifices which contribute to confuta­ tion by an elenchus are prolixity, rapidity, anger, and con­ tention, (which last arise from a man's conducting himself with impudence,) alternate arrangement of questions, and whatever, in short, contribute to concealment, the same are also useful for contentious arguments.
tgt_text.6994: Against contentious opponents, we must interrogate from negation or equally.
tgt_text.6995: 3. Also employ the universal as granted.
tgt_text.6996: 4. Also assuming a proposition through comparison of the quantity.
tgt_text.6998: The sophistical false charge of those who question without syllogistic conclusion, asserting as if a conclusion be made, often contributes to apparent confutation by elenchus.
tgt_text.7000: It is sophistical when a paradox is laid down to chal­ lenge what is apparent.
tgt_text.7002: In elenchtic disputations, as in rhetorical, we must investigate contrarieties.
tgt_text.7004: Also withdraw from the argument, in order to antici­ pate future attack.
tgt_text.7006: Also attack something different to the assertion.
tgt_text.7008: Also state that in elenchi we assert contradiction.
tgt_text.7009: 11. The conclusion must not be questioned after the manner of a proposition.
tgt_text.7012: In this and the following chapters, he pro­ ceeds to discuss the solution of sophistical arguments, and in what their use consists.
tgt_text.7014: They are useful to philosophy, for three reasons, first, as being chiefly from diction, they render us better ac­ quainted with the various ways of predication;
tgt_text.7015: secondly, they contribute to inquiries by oneself, thus precluding self­ deception ;
tgt_text.7016: thirdly, they enhance our fame from giving the appearance of general skill.
tgt_text.7018: To solve a futile argument is not the same thing as to be able quickly to oppose an interrogator;
tgt_text.7019: hence in argu­ mentative as in other exercises, practice is necessary to per­ fection.
tgt_text.7021: We may know the cause of connexion, yet be unable to solve the argument.
tgt_text.7023: XVII.—1. Probable rather than true solution, is some­ times to be sought.
tgt_text.7024: And we must guard, not only against real, but apparent confutation of ourselves.
tgt_text.7026: If that is supposed to be an elenchus, which is accord­ ing to equivocation, the respondent cannot avoid confutation by an elenchus, but wherever there is an ambiguity, it is to be expounded, and the interrogation is not to be simply granted.
tgt_text.7028: Without two interrogations are made one, there will net be a paralogism from ambiguity.
tgt_text.7030: As there may be pseudo elenchi, so also there may be pseudo solutions, which yet are sometimes to be adduced against contentious arguments and duplicity.
tgt_text.7032: We must seem to admit things which seem to be true in order to avoid a parexelenchus.
tgt_text.7034: As things consequent from necessity seem to be parts of the thesis itself, that must be admitted to be the same as the question, which though false or paradoxical, yet results from the thesis, and is required to be granted.
tgt_text.7036: When universal is assumed, not in name, but com­ paratively, the opponent must be said to assume it, not as it was given.
tgt_text.7038: Whoever is excluded from these, must attack the demonstration.
tgt_text.7040: Names properly so called, we must answer either sim­ ply or distinctively.
tgt_text.7042: When the existence of one thing seems necessarily to follow that of another, but not vice versa, the respondent ought to grant the particular rather than the universal.
tgt_text.7043: 11. By transferring names in things asserted by the multitude, and of which there is a double opinion as to truth, a person may escape detection.
tgt_text.7045: Anticipated questions must be previously objected to.
tgt_text.7048: A right solution is the detection of a false syllogism, showing by what questions the falsity occurs.
tgt_text.7050: A syllogism is called false, either if it be falsely con­ cluded, or if, not being a syllogism, it seems to be one.
tgt_text.7052: The solution now treated of as true, is a correction of apparent syllogism, showing from what question it is ap­ parent.
tgt_text.7054: Syllogistic arguments are solved by negation, appa­ rent ones by distinction.
tgt_text.7056: We solve syllogistic arguments, false in the conclusion, by removing some one of the interrogations, and by showing that the conclusion does not thus subsist.
tgt_text.7058: Those which are false according to the propositions, we solve by removing some interrogation only.
tgt_text.7060: Those who desire to solve argument, must first consider its conclusiveness, next, the truth or falsity of its conclusion.
tgt_text.7062: XIX.—1. Of elenchi from equivocation and ambiguity some have an interrogation signifying many things, others have a conclusion multifariously stated.
tgt_text.7064: In the latter case, except the opponent assumes contra­ diction, there is not an elenchus:
tgt_text.7065: in the former, it is not necessary to deny what is two-fold before the distinction is drawn.
tgt_text.7067: The name and the sentence being two-fold, we must partially admit and deny.
tgt_text.7069: In solution of arguments from composition and division, we must state what is contrary to the conclusion.
tgt_text.7071: What is assumed from division is not two-fold, nor are all elenchi from the two-fold.
tgt_text.7073: Where there is different signification, a distinction is to be drawn, by the respondent.
tgt_text.7075: Only a few arguments are derived from accent, the solution of which is easy from the signification of the word being dissimilar, according to the variety of accent.
tgt_text.7078: The error of sophisms founded upon figure of speech, consists in their taking different things for the same, and referring to the same what belong to different categories.
tgt_text.7080: Such sophisms therefore must be solved by distin­ guishing the categories.
tgt_text.7082: XXIII.—1. Sophisms whereof the fault is "in dictione" may all be solved by asserting the contrary to the sophis­ tical assumption, which being affirmed produces the false syllogism.
tgt_text.7085: As to solution of deceptions from accident, we must assert that what is present with the accident need not be with the subject, in other words, we must deny the consequence from the accident to the subject.
tgt_text.7087: Some solve these sophisms by distinguishing the ques­ tion, but in both cases there must be the same correction of arguments derived from the same place, so that this is an inappropriate method of solution.
tgt_text.7089: It is also an imperfect solution to endeavour tc lead to the impossible.
tgt_text.7091: Also to say every number is both great and small, since in reality no conclusion is drawn5.
tgt_text.7092: Some solve them by duplicity, the deception arising from the double sense in which the word is used.
tgt_text.7095: Arguments deduced from what is properly and not simply predicated, we must solve by comparing the opponent's conclusion with our own thesis, in order to as­ certain whether a statement can be made, not simply, but in a certain respect or relation.
tgt_text.7097: A thing may be simply false, but relatively true, also certain things may be true, and yet not true simply.
tgt_text.7100: In solution of arguments from the definition of elenchus, we must consider the conclusion with reference to contradiction, since except there is the latter, there is no elenchus.
tgt_text.7103: —1. Sophisms from petitio principii must not be granted to the inquirer.
tgt_text.7104: 2. If the original question be dubious, the fault must be charged on the questionist.
tgt_text.7106: The defender must plead that he did not grant it for the opponent's use, but in order syllogistically to prove the contrary.
tgt_text.7109: —1. Solution of deceptions from consequents we must draw from the argument itself.
tgt_text.7110: 2. The consequence of consequents is either as universal to particular, or according to oppositions.
tgt_text.7112: XXIX.—1. Whatever syllogistically concludes from some addition, we must observe whether it being taken away, the impossible results, afterwards making this clear, we must state that the respondent granted not what appeared true, but what was adapted to the argument, and the charge of irrelevant argument must be brought against the arguer.
tgt_text.7113: CHAP. XXX.—1. Against sophisms which make many inter­ rogations one, we must use definition immediately at first.
tgt_text.7114: 2. Some arguments of this kind come under the head of equivocation.
tgt_text.7117: In sophisms leading to repetition, we must deny that the categories of relatives signify any thing by themselves.
tgt_text.7119: Diction must not be granted in a direct case.
tgt_text.7122: —In solecisms it must be stated that the oppo­ nent does not really, but only apparently, conclude a sole­ cism, because we seem to have granted what we have not granted.
tgt_text.7125: In some arguments it is easier, in others more difficult, to ascertain the cause of deception, and the argument which may seem to some to be derived from the diction, may to others appear to arise from accident:
tgt_text.7126: that however is the same argument which is derived from the same place.
tgt_text.7127: 2. The most acute argument is that which induces the greatest doubt.
tgt_text.7129: Doubt is two-fold, one in arguments concluding syllo­ gistically as to which proposition is to be denied, the other in contentious arguments, as to how some one should dis­ cuss the proposition.
tgt_text.7131: A syllogistic argument is most acute which subverts what is especially probable from things especially pro­ bable.
tgt_text.7133: The most acute contentious argument is that wherein from the first it is uncertain whether it is syllogistically concluded or not, and whether the solution is from the false or from division.
tgt_text.7135: The argument inconclusive is absurd, if the assump­ tions be very incredible or false, but sometimes it is not altogether despicable.
tgt_text.7137: The querist may argue against the thesis, against the respondent, and against the time.
tgt_text.7140: In recapitulation the reader is reminded of the author's original design in his work, viz. to discover a certain syllogistic faculty about a problem, proposed from things in the highest degree probable, which is the office of the dialectic per se, and also of the peirastic art.
tgt_text.7142: That as true argument may be assailed by sophistry the defence of the thesis in a similar manner, through the greatest probabilities was to be considered.
tgt_text.7144: That the number of problems with their proper sources, also the method and arrangement of interroga­ tions and paralogisms, had been developed.
tgt_text.7146: As the commencement of every thing is perhaps the greatest part of it, so almost all discoveries owe their excellence to an imperfect original, a subsequent partial elaboration, and successive increase, but of dialectic nothing has existed at all.
tgt_text.7148: The schools of contentious arguers for gain, merely afforded a certain kind of instruction, similar to the treatise of Gorgias;
tgt_text.7149: on the other hand, teachers gave rhetorical or interrogative discourses to be learned, according as they thought such to be adapted to their conversation with each other.
tgt_text.7151: Though many old discourses are extant about rhetoric, yet, before Aristotle, none existed concerning the art of syl­ logism, wherefore as the barrenness of the materials ought to plead an excuse for any deficiency in the method, so it should enhance the gratitude felt by the student towards the author of so laborious an investigation.
